{{Infobox basketball biography | name = Angel Goodrich | image =Angel Goodrich at 2 August 2015 game cropped.jpg | caption =Goodrich playing for the [[Seattle Storm]] in 2015 | league = [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]] | position = [[Guard (basketball)|Guard]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1990|2|24}}<ref name="bd">{{cite web |url=http://www.wnba.com/player/angel-goodrich/#/panel-four|title= Angel Goodrich|author=|accessdate=2015-09-30 |year=2015 |publisher=[[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]]}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Glendale, Arizona]] | nationality = American | highschool = [[Sequoyah High School (Tahlequah, Oklahoma)|Sequoyah]] ([[Tahlequah, Oklahoma]]) | college = [[Kansas Jayhawks women's basketball|Kansas]] (2009–2013) | draft_league = WNBA | draft_year = 2013 | draft_round = 3 | draft_pick = 29 | draft_team = [[Tulsa Shock]] | career_start = 2013 | career_end = 2015 | years1 = 2013–2014 | team1 = [[Tulsa Shock]] | years2 = 2014 | team2 = [[Chevakata Vologda]] ([[Russian Women's Basketball Premier League|RPL]]) | years3 = 2015 | team3 = [[Seattle Storm]] | highlights = | wnba_profile = angel_goodrich }} '''Angel Goodrich''' (born February 24, 1990) is an American former professional basketball player, who played for the [[Tulsa Shock]] and [[Seattle Storm]] in the [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]].
==Background and family== Goodrich was born in [[Glendale, Arizona]] to Jonathan and Fayth (Goodrich) Lewis. Jonathan is [[African-American]]; Fayth is Native American ([[Cherokee]]). Goodrich herself is an enrolled member of the [[Cherokee Nation]].<ref name=CNO>{{cite web|title=Cherokee Citizen, Kansas point guard Angel Goodrich inspires Cherokee teens|url=http://www.cherokee.org/News/Stories/33287 |publisher=[[Cherokee Nation]]|date=December 5, 2012|accessdate=August 13, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ND">{{cite web|title=Native Daughters: Angel Goodrich|url=http://cojmc.unl.edu/nativedaughters2/?nd_profile=angel-goodrich|publisher=[[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|UNL]] College of Journalism and Mass Communications|date=November 24, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2015}}</ref><ref name="NN">{{cite web|title=Angel Goodrich (Cherokee) Finishes Second Season in the WNBA for the Tulsa Shock|url=http://nativenewsonline.net/currents/angel-goodrich-cherokee-finishes-second-season-wnba-tulsa-shock/|publisher=nativenewsonline.net|date=August 18, 2014|accessdate=January 19, 2015}}</ref><ref name="cherokee">{{cite web |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2015/02/26/black-history-month-honest-conversation-yawna-allen-being-native-and-black-159388|title= Black History Month: An Honest Conversation With Yawna Allen on Being Native and Black|author=Gyasi Ross|accessdate=2015-03-13 |year=2015 |publisher=[[Indian Country Today Media Network]]}}</ref>
Goodrich has two siblings, an older brother Zach Goodrich, and a younger sister Nikki Lewis. Lewis played college basketball for the [[Tabor College (Kansas)|Tabor]] [[Tabor Bluejays|Bluejays]].<ref name="TC">{{cite web|title=Tabor College: 2013-14 Women's Basketball Roster: #1 Nikki Lewis|url=http://www.taborbluejays.com/roster/11/7/3382.php|publisher=Tabor College|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref>
==High school== Goodrich attended [[Sequoyah High School (Tahlequah, Oklahoma)|Sequoyah High School]] in [[Tahlequah, Oklahoma]], where she was the first [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[athletic scholarship]] recipient in the school's history. During her 4 years at the Cherokee-operated school, she lettered in basketball, softball and track and field, and earned All-State honors as a sprinter. She also led the school's basketball team, the Sequoyah Lady Indians, to three consecutive Class AAA state titles.<ref name="IC">{{cite web|title=The Indomitable Cherokee: University of Kansas's Court General Angel Goodrich|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2012/04/14/indomitable-cherokee-university-kansass-court-general-angel-goodrich-107164|publisher=indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com|date=April 14, 2012|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name="NYT">{{cite web|title=Sequoyah High's Success Energizes Tribe|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/18/sports/18sequoya.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|publisher=New York Times|date=December 18, 2007|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref>
==College== Goodrich played her college basketball for the [[Kansas Jayhawks women's basketball|Kansas Jayhawks]] at the [[University of Kansas]]. In her [[freshman]] year, she tore the [[anterior cruciate ligament]] (ACL) in her left knee, causing her to miss the entire season. The following year she tore the ACL in her right knee after only 15 games. Despite these setbacks, she still scored over 1,000 career points for KU, and became the Jayhawks' all-time career [[Assist (basketball)|assists]] leader. Her assists total of 771 ranks as the third-highest in [[Big 12 Conference]] history.<ref name="IC"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Goodrich becomes 26th to join 1,000-point scoring club|url=http://www.kansan.com/sports/goodrich-becomes-th-to-join--point-scoring-club/article_80b11b4a-b2ee-532a-9f08-12e62162c99e.html|publisher=kansan.com|date=January 23, 2013|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name="WIBW">{{cite web|title=KU’s Angel Goodrich Selected by Tulsa in 2013 WNBA Draft|url=http://www.wibwnewsnow.com/kus-angel-goodrich-selected-by-tulsa-in-2013-wnba-draft/|publisher=wibwnewsnow.com|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref>
In her [[Senior (education)|senior year]], Goodrich was a finalist for the [[Naismith Award]], [[Wade Trophy]], [[John R. Wooden Award|Wooden Award]], [[Nancy Lieberman Award]], and the [[United States Basketball Writers Association|USBWA]] [[Ann Meyers Drysdale]] Award. She also earned First Team All-Big 12 honors, and was a member of the [[Women's Basketball Coaches Association|WBCA]] All-Region 5 Team.<ref name="WIBW"/>
== Kansas statistics == <!-- The stats as added here, September 2017, do not exactly match the stats in the NCAA database as that database has an error. I will send in the notice of the error to the NCAA. In the past, many of my updates to the NCAA have been reflected in the NCAA database. This comment can be removed when the database matches the number shown here. -->
Source<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web1.ncaa.org/stats/StatsSrv/careerplayer|title=NCAA Statistics|website=web1.ncaa.org|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref>{{NBA player statistics legend}} {| class="wikitable" !'''Year''' !'''Team''' !'''GP''' !'''Points''' !'''FG%''' !'''3P%''' !'''FT%''' !'''RPG''' !'''APG''' !'''SPG''' !'''BPG''' !'''PPG''' |- |2008-09 |Kansas | colspan="10" |[[Redshirt (college sports)|redshirt]] |- |2009-10 |Kansas |15 |102 |34.1% |20.0% |50.0% |2.7 |7.1 |1.1 |0.1 |6.8 |- |2010-11 |Kansas |27 |203 |35.8% |28.4% |64.0% |3.0 |6.3 |1.7 |0.1 |7.5 |- |2011-12 |Kansas |'''34''' |476 |'''43.1%''' |'''38.5%''' |65.9% |'''4.1''' |'''7.4''' |2.4 |'''0.4''' |14.0 |- |2012-13 |Kansas |'''34''' |'''481''' |36.5% |31.5% |'''73.0%''' |3.5 |7.2 |'''2.8''' |0.2 |'''14.1''' |- |Career | |127 |1262 |42.3% |33.3% |62.0% |9.6 |0.5 |0.8 |0.8 |9.9 |}
==Professional career== {{Portal|Basketball|Women's sport|Seattle|Biography}} In 2013, Goodrich was selected in the third round of the WNBA draft (29th pick overall) by the Tulsa Shock. At the time she was the highest-drafted Native American player in the history of the WNBA.<ref>{{cite web|title=Native American Women in the WNBA; Schimmel to Join Elite Company|url=http://www.ndnsports.com/native-american-women-in-the-wnba-schimmel-to-join-elite-company/|publisher=NDNSPORTS.com|date=April 8, 2014|accessdate=March 14, 2015}}</ref> During the 2013-14 off-season, she played for [[Chevakata Vologda]] in the [[Russian Women's Basketball Premier League|Russian Premier League]].<ref name="CP">{{cite web|title=Vologda-Chevakata signs Angel Goodrich |url=http://www.cherokeephoenix.org/Article/Index/7701|publisher=cherokeephoenix.org|date=October 16, 2013|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref> In 2014, she completed her second and final season for the Shock. In 2015, she was picked up on waivers by the [[Seattle Storm]].<ref name="NN"/><ref name="IC2">{{cite web|title=KU's Angel Goodrich Highest-Drafted Native Player in WNBA History|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/04/16/kus-angel-goodrich-highest-drafted-native-player-wnba-history-148847|publisher=indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Shock Notebook: Former Tulsa guard Angel Goodrich picked up by Seattle Storm |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/sportsextra/shock/shock-notebook-former-tulsa-guard-angel-goodrich-picked-up-by/article_147122b7-7c98-5921-a734-329827d81bcf.html|publisher=Tulsa World|date=June 7, 2015|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref> In September 2015 Goodrich registered the first double-double (12 points, 10 rebounds) in her three-year WNBA career.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://indiancountrymedianetwork.com/culture/sports/seattle-storm-guard-angel-goodrich-its-all-about-mindset-and-staying-positive/|title=Seattle Storm Guard Angel Goodrich: 'It's All About Mindset and Staying Positive'|last=Harwood|first=Rodney|date=2015-09-16|website=Indian Country Media Network|access-date=2017-09-08}}</ref>
[[File:Goodrich vs Toliver 22.JPG|300px|left|thumb|Angel Goodrich vs [[Kristi Toliver]]]]

{{Infobox person | name = Anthony J. Motley | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = District of Columbia | known_for = | education = | occupation = Pastor, activist, educator | website = http://www.motley2010.com A. Motley Campaign Site for the City Council Position of Councilman At Large | footnotes = }} <!-- some refs added, but needs much more as a BLP -->
Reverend '''Anthony J. Motley''' is an American religious and community leader from Southeast Washington, D.C.
He received his formal education in the [[District of Columbia]] [[Public school (government funded)|Public Schools]], graduating from the Anacostia High School. He served two tours of duty with US military. Motley earned a [[Master of Divinity]] from the [[Howard University]] School of Divinity, and a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in Communications from the University of Detroit.
In 2001 Reverend Motley worked to form what is now the J.O.B.S. Coalition of Greater Washington.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/28/AR2007022801932.html|title=New Doors Open for Students In District|last=Labbé|first=Theola|date=March 1, 2007|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=2009-05-17}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://anacostia.si.edu/exhibits/online_exhibitions/Speak_to_My_Heart/motley.htm "Speak to my Heart: Communities of Faith and Contemporary African American Life.", Interview with Rev. and Mrs. Anthony Motley , Anacostia Museum and Center for African American History and Culture]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Arthur Brown | also known as = The God of Hellfire | image = Arthur_Brown_live.jpg | caption = Brown on stage, August 2009 | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Arthur Wilton Brown | alias = The God of Hellfire | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1942|6|24}} | birth_place = [[Whitby]], [[North Riding of Yorkshire]], England | instrument = Vocals | genre = {{Flatlist| * [[Psychedelic rock]] * [[shock rock]] * [[progressive rock]] * [[rock and roll]] }} | occupation = Musician | years_active = 1965–present | label = [[Track Records|Track]]/[[Polydor Records|Polydor]] | associated_acts = [[Kingdom Come (British band)|Kingdom Come]], [[The Crazy World of Arthur Brown]], Instant Flight, [[Hawkwind]], [[The Alan Parsons Project]] | website = {{URL|arthur-brown.com/|Official site}} }}
'''Arthur Wilton Brown''' (born 24 June 1942)<ref>Marshall 2005, p. 25.</ref> is an English [[rock music|rock]] singer and songwriter best known for his flamboyant theatrical performances, and his powerful, wide-ranging operatic voice. He has been a significant influence on a wide range of musicians due to his operatic vocal style, wild stage persona and concepts, and is considered a pioneer of [[shock rock]] and [[progressive rock]] and influential on [[heavy metal music]].
Brown has been lead singer of various groups, most notably [[the Crazy World of Arthur Brown]] and [[Kingdom Come (British band)|Kingdom Come]], followed by a varied solo career as well as associations with [[Hawkwind]], [[the Who]], [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Klaus Schulze]] and [[Frank Zappa]]. He is best known for his 1968 single "[[Fire (Arthur Brown song)|Fire]]", reaching number one in the [[UK Singles Chart]] and Canada, and number two on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theofficialcharts.com/all_the_no1_songs.php?show=2 |title=Official UK Singles Top 100 – 16th February 2013 | Official UK Top 40 | music charts | Official Singles Chart |publisher= |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
Following the success of the single "Fire", the press would often refer to Brown as "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|The God of Hellfire]]",{{sfn|Echard|2005|p=43}} in reference to the opening shouted line of the song, a moniker that exists to this day.<ref>Unterberger, Richie. ''Urban Spacemen and Wayfaring Strangers'', p. 46.</ref>
==History== Brown was born in Whitby where his parents ran a guest house. After attending [[Roundhay School|Roundhay Grammar School]] in [[Leeds]], Yorkshire, he attended the [[University of London]] and the [[University of Reading]]<ref name="Larkin">Larkin, C., ''Virgin Encyclopedia of Sixties Music'' (Muze UK Ltd, 1997), {{ISBN|0-7535-0149-X}}, p. 77.</ref> and studied philosophy and law, but he gravitated to music instead, forming his first band, Blues and Brown, while at Reading.<ref name="Larkin" /> After a spell fronting a number of bands in London, Brown then moved to Paris in 1966, where he worked on his theatrical skills.<ref name="Larkin" /> During this period he recorded two songs for the [[Roger Vadim]] film of the [[Émile Zola]] novel ''[[La Curée]]''.<ref name="Larkin" /> Returning to London around the turn of 1966 to 1967, he was a temporary member of a London-based [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]]/soul/[[ska]] group [[the Ramong Sound]] that would soon become the hit-making soul group [[the Foundations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psychedelicbabymag.com/2012_01_01_archive.html|title=Arthur Brown interview about Crazy World & Kingdom Come|website=It's Psychedelic Baby|access-date=2017-05-06}}</ref>
===The Crazy World of Arthur Brown=== By the time the Foundations had been signed to [[Pye Records]], Brown had left the group to form his own band, [[the Crazy World of Arthur Brown]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alan-warner.com/10102/info.php?p=5&pno=0 |title=Guitarist/Composer |publisher=Alan Warner |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> The band included [[Vincent Crane]] ([[Hammond organ]] and piano), Drachen Theaker (drums), and Nick Greenwood (bass). Brown quickly earned a reputation for outlandish performances, which included the use of a burning metal helmet, that led to occasional mishaps, such as during an early appearance at the Windsor Festival in 1967, where he wore a colander on his head soaked in methanol. The fuel poured over his head by accident caught fire; a bystander doused the flames by pouring beer on Brown's head, preventing any serious injury.<ref>Marshall 2005, pp. 61–62.</ref> The flaming head then became an Arthur Brown signature. On occasion he also stripped naked while performing, most notably at the Palermo Pop 70 Festival in Sicily, Italy, July 1970, where he was arrested and deported.<ref>Marshall 2005, pp. 94–101.</ref> He was also notable for the extreme make-up he wore onstage, which would later be reflected in the stage acts of [[Alice Cooper]] and [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]].<ref name="Vice"/><ref name="RS"/> He was also famed for his powerful operatic baritone voice and his high pitched screams.
By 1968, the debut album, ''[[The Crazy World of Arthur Brown (album)|The Crazy World of Arthur Brown]]'' became a hit on both sides of the Atlantic. Produced by [[the Who]]'s manager [[Kit Lambert]], and executive-produced by [[Pete Townshend]] on Track Records, the label begun by Lambert and [[Chris Stamp]], it spun off an equally surprising hit single, "[[Fire (Arthur Brown song)|Fire]]", and contained a version of "[[I Put a Spell on You]]" by [[Screamin' Jay Hawkins]], a similarly bizarre showman. "Fire" sold over one million copies, and was awarded a [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]].<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs">{{Cite book| first= Joseph| last= Murrells| year= 1978| title= The Book of Golden Discs| edition= 2nd| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins| location= London| page= 236| isbn= 0-214-20512-6}}</ref> The song has since seen its opening line "I am the God of Hellfire" [[Sampling (music)|sampled]] in numerous other places, most notably in [[the Prodigy]]'s 1992 rave anthem "[[Fire/Jericho|Fire]]".<ref name="Vice"/><ref name="RS"/>
In the late 1960s, the Crazy World of Arthur Brown's popularity was such that the group shared bills with [[the Who]], [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[the Mothers of Invention]], [[the Doors]], [[the Small Faces]], and [[Joe Cocker]], among others.<ref>Richie Unterberger (2014). "Urban Spacemen & Wayfaring Strangers [Revised & Expanded Ebook Edition]: Overlooked Innovators & Eccentric Visionaries of '60s Rock". BookBaby</ref> Theaker was replaced because of his [[aviophobia]] in 1968 by drummer [[Carl Palmer]], later of [[Atomic Rooster]] and [[Emerson, Lake & Palmer]], for the band's second American tour in 1969, on which keyboardist Vincent Crane also left – although he soon returned.<ref name="Larkin" /> However, Crane and Palmer eventually left in June 1969 to form [[Atomic Rooster]], spelling the end for the Crazy World of Arthur Brown.<ref name="Larkin" />
===Arthur Brown's Kingdom Come=== Though Brown never released another recording as commercially successful as "Fire", he worked with a varied group of musicians on projects called Strangelands, Puddletown Express, and (briefly) the [[Captain Beefheart]]-influenced Rustic Hinge, before releasing three albums with his new band [[Kingdom Come (British band)|Kingdom Come]] in the early 1970s.<ref name="Larkin" /><ref>Marshall 2005, pp. 106–111.</ref>{{#tag:ref|Arthur Brown's Kingdom Come has no link with the American/German [[Kingdom Come (band)|hard-rock/glam band of the same name]].|group=N}}
[[File:EMS VCS 3 synthesizer (1969, SN 297) & DK-1 keyboard (1969), Musée de la Musique de Paris.jpg|thumb|left|Victor Peraino used the [[EMS VCS 3]] synthesizer on the album ''[[Journey (Kingdom Come album)|Journey]]''.]] The three Kingdom Come albums each have a distinctive character. The first was a highly complex concept album apparently on the theme of humanity living in a zoo and being controlled by cosmic, religious and commercial forces. The second was loosely on the theme of water, which Brown had declared four years earlier would be the subject of the second album by the Crazy World. It was musically more conventional than the first, much less heavy, though stranger in places. The third album, ''[[Journey (Kingdom Come album)|Journey]]'' (1973), recorded in [[Rockfield Studios]] in Wales, was a space rock album, with Brown playing an early [[drum machine]] and thereby replacing a series of drummers. The band also recorded three of its songs in a live [[Peel Session]] for the [[John Peel]] [[BBC Radio 1]] show on 25 September 1972.<ref name="booklet1" /> Richie Unterberger of [[Allmusic]] said that the album has been "most noted in retrospect as one of the first rock records to use a drum machine, which was still quite a novelty back in 1973."<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/journey-mw0000320953|title=Journey – Arthur Brown's Kingdom Come, Arthur Brown – Songs, Reviews, Credits – AllMusic|website=AllMusic|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> Brown recalled "the whole album is based around the drum machine, and we had a lot of ideas that we wanted to explore using this technology.<ref>Journey (liner). Kingdom Come. Esoteric Recordings. 2010.</ref> The drum machine they used was the Bentley Rhythm Ace, the British version of the FR-1.<ref name="booklet1">{{cite AV media notes| title = Journey| others= Kingdom Come| year = 2003| type = liner| publisher = Castle Music}}</ref>
The stage acts for all three albums featured a wild mix of special effects, dramatic costumes and colourful theatrics, which were sometimes controversial. Brown had declared when Kingdom Come was formed that the intention was to create a multi-media experience and the band always followed that policy. The concepts, the music and the theatrics proved very popular on the university circuit but proved too way-out for a mainstream audience. The band appeared at the 1971 [[Glastonbury Festival]] in Somerset, England and featured in the [[Glastonbury Fayre]] film which was shown in cinemas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukrockfestivals.com/glasmenu.html |title=The Glastonbury Festival 1971 |publisher=Ukrockfestivals.com |date=1971-06-26 |accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref>
===Later career=== In later years, Brown released several solo albums. In 1975, he appeared in [[the Who]]'s rock opera movie ''[[Tommy (1975 film)|Tommy]]'' as "The Priest".<ref name="Larkin" /> Later that year he contributed vocals to the song "The Tell-Tale Heart" on the [[Edgar Allan Poe|Poe]]-based [[concept album]] ''[[Tales of Mystery and Imagination (Alan Parsons Project album)|Tales of Mystery and Imagination]]'' by [[the Alan Parsons Project]]. In 1979 and 1980, he collaborated with German electronic musician [[Klaus Schulze]], and can be heard on the albums ''[[Dune (Klaus Schulze album)|Dune]]'', ''[[...Live...]]'' and ''[[Time Actor]]''.<ref>Jenkins, Mark (2009). "Analog Synthesizers: Understanding, Performing, Buying—From the Legacy of Moog to Software Synthesis". P. 150. CRC Press</ref>
In the 1980s, Brown moved to [[Austin, Texas]], where his wife came from, and obtained a master's degree in counselling.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Return of the Hellfire God: Arthur Brown Is Back and Still Crazy After 47 Years|url=http://www.laweekly.com/music/the-return-of-the-hellfire-god-arthur-brown-is-back-and-still-crazy-after-47-years-7930779|agency=LA Weekly|date=2 January 2018}}</ref> On 17 January 1987, Brown performed "Fire" on the "Flashback" segment of the television programme ''[[Solid Gold (TV series)|Solid Gold]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.tv.com/shows/solid-gold/solid-gold-87-show-16-w-chicago-385850/ |title=Solid Gold – Season 7, Episode 16: Solid Gold 87 Show 16 w/ Chicago |publisher=TV.com |date=5 February 2008 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Together with former [[The Mothers of Invention|Mothers of Invention]] drummer [[Jimmy Carl Black]], he also became a painter and carpenter for some years,<ref name="Larkin" /> and released an album with him, ''Brown, Black & Blue'' (1988). In 1992, Brown and fellow counsellor Jim Maxwell founded Healing Songs Therapy, a service that culminated in Brown creating a song for each client about their emotional issues.<ref>Marshall 2005, pp. 204–206.</ref>
[[File:Arthur Brown.jpg|thumb|right|Arthur Brown playing at the [[Wickerman Festival]], 2005]]
Brown returned to England in 1996. In 1997, he re-recorded "Fire" with German band [[Die Krupps]], while in 1998, he provided a spoken-word performance on [[Bruce Dickinson]]'s ''[[The Chemical Wedding (Bruce Dickinson album)|The Chemical Wedding]]'' album, reading a portion of three poems by [[William Blake]], and appeared as Satan in Dickinson's music video for "Killing Floor". He was narrator for [[the Pretty Things]]' live performance of their album ''[[S. F. Sorrow]]'' (1998) at [[Abbey Road Studios]]. He also appeared on television, guesting on [[Kula Shaker]] track "Mystical Machine Gun" several times during 1999.
A further change of musical direction occurred, when he formed an acoustic band and went on tour with [[Tim Rose]] in 1999. This band then added Stan Adler (cello and bass) and [[Malcolm Mortimore]] (percussion) and produced the album ''Tantric Lover'' (2000). However, the lineup did not last, and Brown put a new band together with guitarist Rikki Patten and multi-instrumentalist [[Nick Pynn]]. In 2002, Brown was asked to support [[Robert Plant]] on his Dreamland Tour. By now Patten had been replaced by guitarist Chris Bryant. Brown was getting some more media exposure now. His band was briefly called the Giant Pocket Orchestra, and also Instant Flight. In the middle of this, in 2003, Brown released ''Vampire Suite'' (2003), an album with Josh Philips and [[Mark Brzezicki]] of the band [[Big Country]], released on Ian Grant's [[Track Records]].<ref>[https://www.allmusic.com/album/vampire-suite-mw0000321481 "Vampire Suite"]. AllMusic. Retrieved 4 January 2018</ref> Also around this time, Brown's back catalogue was re-released by [[Sanctuary Records]]. [[File:The Crazy World of Arthur Brown (15396473559).jpg|thumb|left|The Crazy World of Arthur Brown at Musicport in [[Whitby]], England in 2014]] Brown reunited the surviving members of Kingdom Come (except Des Fisher) in 2005, for a one-off concert at The Astoria in London, performing material from Kingdom Come's album ''Galactic Zoo Dossier'', with an encore of "Spirit of Joy". This show won Brown the 'Showman of the Year' award from ''[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]]'' magazine, with Brown receiving the award at the [[Classic Rock Roll of Honour Awards]] ceremony held in London's [[Café de Paris (London)|Café de Paris]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Classic Rock Roll of Honour Awards: Winners Announced|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/classic-rock-roll-of-honour-awards-winners-announced/|agency=Blabbermouth|date=2 January 2018}}</ref> In 2007, Brown and Pynn released ''Voice of Love'' on the Côte Basque record label, featuring a number of original recordings.<ref>[https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-voice-of-love-mw0000484861 "The Voice of Love"]. AllMusic. Retrieved 2 January 2018</ref>
In August 2007, during a concert in [[Lewes]], East Sussex, England, Brown once again set fire to his own hair. While trying to extinguish the flames, Phil Rhodes, a member of the band also caught fire. Brown carried on after the fire was put out; he had however lost a few chunks of hair.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.sussexexpress.co.uk/news/God-of-Hellfire-Arthur-Brown.3160077.jp |title=God of Hellfire Arthur Brown burnt in stage stunt – Local |publisher=''Sussex Express'' |date=30 August 2007 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> He appeared as a priest in the [[music video|video]] for [[The Darkness (band)|the Darkness]] song, "[[Is It Just Me?]]". In 2009, a roll-out re-release of Brown's back catalogue was commenced by [[Cherry Red Records]]' subsidiary Lemon Recordings and continued from 2010 onwards on their sister label [[Esoteric Recordings]].<ref>[http://www.cherryredlicensing.co.uk/cherry-red-are-proud-to-be-the-custodians-of-arthur-browns-catalogue/ "Cherry Red are proud to be the custodians of Arthur Brown’s catalogue!"]. Cherry Red Records. Retrieved 2 January 2018</ref>
In 2010, Brown played a set at the [[Glastonbury Festival]] in the Glade. On 10 June 2011, days before his 69th birthday, he played at the [[Ray Davies]] [[Meltdown (festival)|Meltdown Festival]] at the [[Queen Elizabeth Hall]], London where he invited [[Z-Star]] to duet with him. Six weeks later, again in London, he played the [[High Voltage Festival]]; the gig was recorded and released (on vinyl only) as ''The Crazy World of Arthur Brown Live at High Voltage''. In 2012, Brown and Rick Patten released ''The Magic Hat'' alongside a comic of the same title by [[Matt Howarth]] – a curious, cross-dimensional adventure facilitated by a flaming helmet. In 2013, as the result of a successful pledge campaign on [[PledgeMusic]], Brown released the album "Zim Zam Zim" based on the cosmos having recorded it in his [[yurt]] in [[Lewes]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://drownedinsound.com/in_depth/4148135-the-life-of-arthur-brown-and-zim-zam-zim |title=The Life of Arthur Brown and 'Zim Zam Zim' |last=Whyte |first=Woodrow |date=29 August 2014 |website=[[Drowned in Sound]]}}</ref> On 2 July 2017, the Crazy World of Arthur Brown performed at the [[Royal Albert Hall]]'s Elgar Room.<ref>[https://www.royalalberthall.com/about-the-hall/news/2017/july/in-pictures-the-crazy-world-of-arthur-brown-wreak-havoc-in-the-elgar-room/ "In pictures: The Crazy World of Arthur Brown wreak havoc in the Elgar Room"]. Royal Albert Hall. Retrieved 2 January 2018</ref>
==Influence== {{quote box | quote = Almost 50 years ago, musical icon Arthur Brown stepped out on stage, five-foot tall flames leaping from his head, and uttered one of rock music’s most stirring lines: “I am the God of Hellfire.” At that point, the British theatrical rocker who brought us [[the Crazy World of Arthur Brown]] in '68 had no way of knowing that he would come to be seen as a major pioneer in not only progressive rock and heavy metal, but the entire concept of what makes a stage show. He’s influenced generations of musicians who searched for an edge, from [[King Diamond]], [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]], and [[Peter Gabriel]] to [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]], [[Rob Halford]], and [[Alice Cooper]]. | source = —"The God of Hellfire Speaks: 73 Years Inside the Crazy World of Arthur Brown", [[Vice (magazine)|''Vice'' magazine]], 2013.<ref name="Vice">[https://noisey.vice.com/da/article/695kpv/crazy-world-of-arthur-brown-interview "The God of Hellfire Speaks: 73 Years Inside the Crazy World of Arthur Brown"]. ''Vice''. Retrieved 29 December 2017</ref> | width = 35% | align = right | style = padding:8px; }} Though Brown has had limited commercial success and has never released another recording as commercially successful as "Fire", he has been a significant influence on [[Alice Cooper]],<ref>Marshall 2005, pp. 85 and 153.</ref> [[David Bowie]], [[Peter Gabriel]],<ref>Marshall 2005, p. 175.</ref> [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]],<ref name="Vice"/> [[George Clinton (musician)|George Clinton]],<ref>Marshall 2005, p. 172.</ref> [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]], [[King Diamond]], [[Rob Halford]] of [[Judas Priest]] and [[Bruce Dickinson]] of [[Iron Maiden]],<ref>Marshall 2005, p. 103.</ref> among others, and his songs have been covered or sampled by a range of artists including [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[the Prodigy]], Marilyn Manson and [[the Who]].<ref name="Vice"/><ref name="RS">[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/arthur-brown-on-shock-rock-hendrix-close-calls-with-fire-w463039 "Arthur Brown on Shock Rock, Hendrix, Close Calls With Fire"]. ''Rolling Stone''. Retrieved 29 December 2017</ref>
Brown's voice, and in particular his high banshee screams, are a precursor to the banshee screaming of many later [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] singers, and his theatrical concepts and stage presence such as the face makeup, especially his black and white face paint ([[corpse paint]]), voodoo dancing, and flaming helmet pioneered a lot of what was to become [[shock rock]] and [[progressive rock]].<ref name="Vice"/><ref name="RS"/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Miles|first1=Barry|title=The British Invasion: Arthur Brown|date=2009|publisher=Sterling Publishing Company, Inc.,|page=274|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r8xbaIlrUREC&pg=PA274&dq=arthur+brown+black+and+white+face+paint&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi52bri66_YAhVsBcAKHTphAwcQ6AEIKTAB#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> The third and final Kingdom Come album, ''[[Journey (Kingdom Come album)|Journey]]'' (1973), is noteworthy for being one of the first rock albums to feature a [[drum machine]], especially on the track "Time Captives".<ref>Marshall 2005, pp. 121–125.</ref>
==Hawkwind association== Brown has had a number of associations with [[Hawkwind]]. In 1973, he was one of the performers on [[Robert Calvert]]'s album ''[[Captain Lockheed and the Starfighters]]'', together with a number of other Hawkwind members.<ref name="Hawkwind"/>
In 2001 and 2002, Brown made several guest appearances at live Hawkwind concerts, subsequently touring with them as a guest vocalist. On their December 2002 tour, Hawkwind played several songs by Brown from the Kingdom Come era, along with "Song of the Gremlin", which Brown had sung on ''[[Captain Lockheed and the Starfighters]]''; this was documented on the Hawkwind DVD ''[[Hawkwind videography#Out of the Shadows|Out of the Shadows]]''.<ref name="Hawkwind">[https://www.allmusic.com/album/captain-lockheed-and-the-starfighters-mw0000201272 "Captain Lockheed and the Starfighters"]. AllMusic. Retrieved 4 January 2018</ref>
Brown also provided vocals on two of the tracks on Hawkwind's studio album ''[[Take Me to Your Leader (Hawkwind album)|Take Me to Your Leader]]'', released in 2005.<ref name="Leader">[https://www.allmusic.com/album/take-me-to-your-leader-cd-dvd-mw0000761646 "Take Me to Your Leader"]. AllMusic. Retrieved 4 January 2018</ref> One is the spoken-word "A Letter to Robert", where Brown recalls a conversation with [[Robert Calvert]].<ref name="Leader"/> Brown continued his association with Hawkwind, touring with a support set for them on their 40th anniversary tour in the United Kingdom in 2009. In 2018, Brown was a guest vocalist on the first five dates of Hawkwind’s UK tour.<ref>[https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Arthur-Brown-Joins-As-Vocalist-On-Hawkwinds-UK-Tour-Starts-1018-20181010 “Arthur Brown Joins As Vocalist On Hawkwind's UK Tour, Starts 10/18”]. BroadwayWorld. Retrieved 25 October 2018</ref>
==Selected discography==

Side to be B Side the C Side" ''(Kingdom Come)'' ([[Polydor Records]] 2001 234 UK) *1973: "Spirit of Joy" b/w "Come Alive" (Polydor 2001 416 UK) *1974: "Gypsies" b/w "Dance" (Gull Records GULS 4 UK) *1975: "[[We've Gotta Get Out of This Place]]" b/w "Here I Am" (Gull GULS 13 UK)

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Orphan|date=March 2014}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Photo of Atima Srivastava.jpeg|thumbnail|right|Atima Srivastava]] --> '''Atima Srivastava''' (born 1961 in Mumbai, India) is an author and director who lives in London. She has written [[short stories]], authored two books, and has done multiple film directing and editing projects. Srivastava has won several awards for her work in film and literature. She also teaches and designs creative writing programs in universities throughout Europe.<ref name="paddy">{{cite web|url=http://www.paddyfield.com.hk/authors/atimasrivastava/author.html |title=Atima Srivastava |publisher=Paddyfield.com.hk |date= |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref>
==Early life== Atima Srivastava was born in [[Mumbai]], India in 1961. When she was eight years old, she moved to London with her family, where she still lives today.
==Education== Srivastava attended the Moat Mount School, now the [[Mill Hill County High School]], in the 1970s. In 1980 she entered the [[University of Essex]] where she earned her bachelor's degree in 1983.<ref name="brit">{{cite web|author=British Council |url=http://literature.britishcouncil.org/atima-srivastava |title=Atima Srivastava | British Council Literature |publisher=Literature.britishcouncil.org |date=2014-05-19 |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref>
==Career==
===Writing=== Srivastava wrote her first novel, ''Transmission'', in 1992. The story follows a young semi-autobiographibcal Anglo-Indian woman named Angie, who, much like Srivastava, works as a film producer. The book focuses on the relationships that Angie has with her parents, an old-fashioned and authoritarian Indian couple, and with Lol and Kathi, an [[HIV]]-positive couple about whom she wants to make a documentary and with whom she has a romantic affair. The title comes from the book's examination of several forms of transmission, the transmission of Indian culture and lifestyle into modern London and of sexually transmitted diseases.
In 2000 Srivastava published her second book, ''Looking for Maya''. The plot tells of another young Anglo-Indian woman, Mira, who works as an author in London. Mira is forced to overcome issues of identity, love, tradition, and modernity as she attempts to find meaning while switching from one romantic entanglement to another.<ref name="brit" /> Both novels have [[protagonist]]s who, instead of spiralling into an existential identity crisis over nationality and culture choose to focus on minor events in the characters' lives and their relation to a greater pursuit for love, success, and happiness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://atimasrivastava.bookchums.com/ |title=Atima Srivastava Author of Transmission (90s),Books,Bio,Short Stories, Novels, Read Books of Atima |publisher=Atimasrivastava.bookchums.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref>
Srivastava also written several short stories which have been published in anthologies such as ''New Writing 2001'', ''Well-Sorted'', and ''Tran-Lit''.
She is working on a third novel titled ''The Non-Resident Indian''.<ref name="paddy" />
===Film and theatre=== Since 1985, Srivastava has worked as a film editor and director. In 1993 she helped produce a TV documentary ''Moving Pictures'' which is a journalism series reporting on global cinema.<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3350703/</ref> She also has written three TV-movie screenplays, ''Dancing in the Dark'' and ''The Legendary Vindaloo'' for Channel 4, and ''Camden Story'' for the BBC. In addition, the [[National Theatre Company]] commissioned her to write a play titled ''Why Not Love?'' which premiered in 2001.<ref name="paddy" />
===Teaching=== Srivastava has done a significant amount of work as a lecturer and curriculum designer for both British and European universities. In 2000 she worked as a lecturer at the New York University-London program where she taught creative writing and at CAPA International Education where she taught a course called Writing the City in addition to creative writing. She also taught various writing and film technique and development courses at IES Abroad between 2002 and 2007 and taught creative writing at the [[University of Greenwich]] from 2007 to 2009.<ref name="brit" /> Her books have been studied at universities in Poland, Spain, and Russia.
She was also the British author-in-residence at the Universities of Singapore, Sophia in Bulgaria, Mumbai, Berne, Cologne, Mainz, Ewha in Seoul, Connecticut College (USA) and Warwick University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fie.org.uk/london/londonfaculty/atima_srivastava/ |title=London Faculty | FIE: Foundation for International Education |publisher=FIE |date= |accessdate=2014-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222035526/http://www.fie.org.uk/london/londonfaculty/atima_srivastava/ |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref>
==Awards== Srivastava has won several awards for film and literature. She won the Bridgeport Short Story Prize in 1994 for her short story ''Dragons in E8''. She has won two Arts Council Writers' Awards, one in 1998 for her book ''Looking for Maya'', and one in 2000 for her unreleased third book. Also in 2000 she received the Hawthornden Fellowship and was a finalist at the London Writers' Competition.<ref name="brit" />

'''Bo Jiang''', a contract researcher working on "source code for high technology imaging" at [[NASA]]'s [[Langley Research Center]], was arrested under a charge of lying to federal officer on March 16, 2013 at [[Dulles International Airport]] on his planned one-way journey to return to China. He was accused of espionage by Representative [[Frank Wolf (politician)|Frank Wolf]], and was investigated for possible violations of the [[Arms Export Control Act]].<ref name=Lambidakis>{{cite web|last=Lambidakis|first=Stephanie|title=Update: NASA researcher arrested on China-bound plane|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57575014/nasa-researcher-arrested-on-china-bound-plane/|publisher=[[CBS Interactive Inc.]]|accessdate=20 March 2013|date=19 March 2013}}</ref> An affidavit claimed that on a prior occasion, Jiang had taken a NASA laptop containing sensitive information to China.<ref name=HuffPo>{{cite web|last=Howard|first=Jacqueline|title=Bo Jiang, Former NASA Contractor, Arrested By FBI On Plane To China|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/19/bo-jiang-arrested-nasa-spy-fbi-china_n_2908082.html|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=20 March 2013|date=18 March 2013}}</ref>
Jiang was released on May 2, 2013, after a plea agreement in which he admitted guilt to a single charge of misuse of Federal office equipment to download copyrighted movies, television shows and pornography.<ref name="Pilot-May2013" />
==Arrest and Plea Bargain== On March 28, 2013, a U.S. Judge ordered Jiang released after a federal prosecutor acknowledged there was no evidence that he possessed any sensitive, secret or classified material.<ref name=Hamptonroads.com>{{cite web|last=Sizemore|first=Bill|title=Chinese ex-NASA worker to be released pending trial|url=http://hamptonroads.com/2013/03/chinese-exnasa-worker-be-released-pending-trial|publisher=Hamptonroads|accessdate=28 March 2013|date=28 March 2013}}</ref> Jiang's lawyer said congressman Wolf was making his client a "scapegoat" and the subject of witch hunt.<ref name=DailyPress>{{cite web|last=Dujardin|first=Peter|title=Attorney: Former NASA contractor subject of 'witch hunt'|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/2013-03-21/news/dp-nws-nasa-contractor-hearing-20130321_1_jiang-last-week-federal-court-federal-agents|publisher=Daily Press|accessdate=21 March 2013|date=21 March 2013}}</ref>
On May 2, 2013, prosecutors dropped a felony charge of lying to federal investigators.<ref name=NIA>{{cite web|title=NIA STATEMENT ON THE RELEASE OF DR. BO JIANG|url=http://www.nianet.org/press-releases/nia-statement-on-the-release-of-dr-bo-jiang/|accessdate=10 Nov 2013|date=3 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="Pilot-May2013">{{cite web|title=Chinese scientist freed after felony case collapses|url=https://pilotonline.com/news/local/crime/article_f46ec17d-d7df-5e12-a128-52ea58f19a97.html|accessdate=20 July 2018|publisher=''The Virginian-Pilot''|last=Sizemore|first=Bill|date=3 May 2013}}</ref> Jiang pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanor count of misusing government office equipment and was sentenced to time served - about seven weeks. In his plea agreement, Jiang acknowledged violating a NASA regulation governing use of government office equipment by downloading copyrighted movies, television shows and sexually explicit images on the NASA-owned laptop.<ref name="Pilot-May2013" />
On October 26, 2015 Congressman John Culberson announced the indictment of two Langley Research Center supervisors, accusing them of complicity in "espionage" in the affair.<ref name=Culberson>{{cite web|last=Culberson|first=John|title=Culberson Reaction to Indictment of NASA Supervisors|url=http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=47156 |publisher=SpaceRef|accessdate=29 Oct 2015|date=29 Oct 2015}}</ref> However no evidence of espionage was ever presented.

revision.comment: /* top */proper dab redirect, replaced: [[University of Queensland]]. She has many published works about feminism, [[socialism]], literature and culture. She has been the editor of the [[radical feminist]] academic journal using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}} '''Carole Ferrier''' is an [[Australian feminist]] academic. She is [[Professor#Most other English-speaking countries|Professor]] in [[English Literature|English]] at the School of English, Media Studies and Art History at the [[University of Queensland]]. She has many published works about feminism, [[socialism]], literature and culture. She has been the editor of the [[radical feminist]] academic journal ''[[Hecate (journal)|Hecate]]'' since its inception in 1975.
==Early life== Ferrier was awarded a [[Bachelor of Arts]] Degree with [[Honours degree#Honours degrees and academic distinctions|Honours]] in [[London]], and a [[PhD]] in [[New Zealand]], at the [[University of Auckland]].<ref name="Biography - uqresearchers">{{cite web | url=http://researchers.uq.edu.au/researcher/348 | title=Professor Carole Ferrier | work=UQ Researchers | accessdate=July 28, 2015}}</ref> Ferrier helped establish the [[International Socialist Tendency]] in Australia in the 1970s,<ref>"[http://redsites.alphalink.com.au/marching.rtf Marching down Marx Street: The International Socialists in Australia, 1972-92.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110216201842/http://redsites.alphalink.com.au/marching.rtf |date=16 February 2011 }}", ''Tom O'Lincoln's Red Sites'', 1992. Accessed: 26 August 2010.</ref> and was a prominent activist in various democratic rights struggles in Queensland from the 1970s.<ref>Raymond Evans and Carole Ferrier eds. ''Radical Brisbane'', Melbourne: [[Vulgar Press]], 2004</ref>
==Academic work== Ferrier has lectured in English at the University of Queensland since 1973.<ref name="Biography - uqresearchers"/> She is currently Professor of Literature and Women's Studies at the School of Communication and Arts<ref>http://communication-arts.uq.edu.au/carole-ferrier</ref> at the University of Queensland. Ferrier is also the Director of the Women, Gender, Culture and Social Change Research Group at the University of Queensland, a former president of the Australian Women's Studies Association<ref>[http://www.emsah.uq.edu.au/awsr/awsa/contacts.html AWSA Director President: Carole Ferrier/ - uqresearchers]</ref> and editor of ''Hecate'' and the ''Australian Women's Book Review''.<ref name="Professor Carole Ferrier">[http://www.emsah.uq.edu.au/index.html?page=17750&pid= Professor Carole Ferrier]</ref>
==Publications and editorial work== Amongst her many other published works, Ferrier has authored ''Jean Devanny: Romantic Revolutionary'' ([[Melbourne University Press]], 1999).
She has also edited * ''Hecate: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Women's Liberation'' (as foundation editor])<ref>[http://www.emsah.uq.edu.au/awsr/Publ_Hecate/hecate.htm Hecate]</ref> * ''Radical Brisbane: An Unruly History''. Melbourne: [[Vulgar Press]] 2004. (with [[Raymond Evans (writer)|Raymond Evans]]) * ''Gender, Politics and Fiction: 20th Century Australian Women's Novels''. [[University of Queensland Press|St Lucia: UQP]], 1992. * ''Point of Departure: The Autobiography of [[Jean Devanny]]''. St Lucia: UQP, 1986. * ''As Good as a Yarn With You: Letters Between Franklin, Prichard, Devanny, Barnard, Eldershaw and Dark.'' Sydney: [[Cambridge University Press]], 1994. * ''[[Janet Frame]]: A Reader.'' London: Women's Press,<ref>[http://www.the-womens-press.com/ Women's Press]</ref> 1995.<ref name="Professor Carole Ferrier"/>
==Criticism== Ferrier's 1992 book '''Gender, Politics and Fiction''' was criticised as using orthodox [[Marxism|Marxist]] doctrine, the [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]] of [[Paul Feyerabend|Feyerabend]] and [[Thomas Kuhn]], the [[post-structuralist]] work of [[Jacques Derrida]] and [[Gilles Deleuze]] into an "epistemic certainty".<ref name="The Age - 01Sep1968 - Zhbanov">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1FsQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-pIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5795,413525&dq=carole-ferrier&hl=en|title=Zhbanov|date=1 September 1986|work=[[The Age]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of feminists]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Curtis Howe Springer | image = Curtishowespringer-9-1930.jpg | caption = Springer in an advertisement from September 1930. | birth name = | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1896|12|2}} | birth_place = [[Birmingham, Alabama]] | residence = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|1985|8|19|1896|12|2}} | death_place = [[Las Vegas, Nevada]] | occupation = [[Radio evangelist]] | denomination = | spouse = Mary Louise Berkebile (divorced)
Helen Springer (his death) | children = Curtis Jr., Marilou | networth = | website = | signature = }} '''Curtis Howe Springer''' (December 2, 1896 – August 19, 1985) was an American [[radio evangelism|radio evangelist]], self-proclaimed [[Physician|medical doctor]] and [[Methodism|Methodist]] minister best known for founding the [[Zzyzx, California|Zzyzx]] Mineral Springs resort located within [[Southern California]]'s [[Mojave Desert]]. He was also the host of well-known [[evangelical]] [[broadcast syndication|syndicated radio]] programs that were broadcast throughout the United States for several decades. Springer was in actuality neither a doctor nor a minister,{{cite news |title=Zzyzx |first=Ross |last=Eckler |work=[[Word Ways: The Journal of Recreational Linguistics]] |issn=0043-7980 |year=1996 |url=http://www.wordways.com/zzyzx.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061109224417/http://www.wordways.com/zzyzx.htm |archivedate=November 9, 2006 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=September 15, 2016 |df=mdy }} and he described himself as the "last of the old-time [[medicine men]]." {{cite news|title=Zzyzx now last word in research|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tFcyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KuYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6878,2949415&dq=zzyzx+curtis&hl=en|work=[[Lawrence Journal-World]]|date=18 November 1976|page=32}} In 1969, the [[American Medical Association]] labeled him the "King of [[Quackery|Quacks]]".{{cite news | first=Cecilia |last=Rasmussen |work=Los Angeles Times | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/jun/16/local/me-then16 | title=Zzyzx: An Unlikely Home of Hucksterism and Miracle Cures| date=16 June 2002}} In the early 1970s, the [[US Government|federal government]] discovered that Springer held no legal rights to the land where Zzyzx stood; consequently, he was evicted from the space and briefly imprisoned. ==Biography== === Personal life === Curtis Howe Springer was born December 2, 1896, and hailed from [[Birmingham, Alabama|Wheeling, West Virgina.]] He was married to Mary Louise Berkebile. They separated at some point, and he married a woman named Helen.US Court Record: "[http://ftp.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/478/478.F2d.43.71-2309.html Rehearing Denied March 5, 1973] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310145317/http://ftp.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/478/478.F2d.43.71-2309.html |date=March 10, 2012 }}." – Helen Springer is listed as Curtis' wife. Springer had several children, including a daughter, Marilou, and a son, Curtis Jr., who later became a judge in [[Montgomery, Alabama]].{{cite news|title=Oswalt - Gilpin Wedding|url=http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20100620/CELEBRATE01/100621008/1001/rss01|work=Montgomery Advertiser|date=21 June 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113233624/http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20100620/CELEBRATE01/100621008/1001/rss01|archivedate=January 13, 2015 }} === Early career === He claimed to have been a [[private (rank)|private]] in the [[United States Army]], where he taught boxing.{{cite book |title=Jazz Age: People and Perspectives |first=Mitchell |last=Newton-Matza |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=MX6fLIDvWKUC&pg=PA69 |pages=69–70|publisher=ABC-CLIO|date=2009|isbn=9781598840339}} In Springer's early life, he "drummed up crowds for [[William Jennings Bryan]]'s tirades [[Prohibition in the United States|against demon rum]]" and was a [[sheet music]] vendor at [[Billy Sunday]]'s [[evangelical]] services.{{cite news |work=Daytona Beach Morning Journal |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=p4gfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lcsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=788,4132398&dq=zzyzx&hl=en |title=Improbable Name, But... Zzyzx is a Booming Health Spa|first=Stephen V.|last=Roberts|date=19 July 1970|page=8B}} Following [[World War I]], Springer worked at a school in [[Florida]]. In the late 1920s, Springer moved to [[Chicago]], where he became involved with an automotive technical school called Greer College.{{cite journal|title=Bureau of Investigation: Curtis Howe Springer, A Quack and his Nostrums|journal=[[Journal of the American Medical Association]]|date=14 September 1935|volume=105|issue=11|page=900|doi=10.1001/jama.1935.02760370056027}} Springer was fired by 1930, and the school was forced into [[bankruptcy]] shortly afterward. Throughout the 1930s, Curtis Springer gave lectures throughout the midwestern United States, claiming to either to be the "Dean of Greer College", or that he represented/attended the fictional institutions of the National Academy, The Springer School of Humanism, the American College of Doctors and Surgeons, the Westlake West Virginia College, and two non-existent [[osteopathy]] schools in [[Meyersdale, Pennsylvania]] and [[New Jersey]]. Although all his lectures were "free", Springer would ask for [[donations]] part-way through his speech, and often attempt to sell audience members private courses in [[psychoanalysis]] for $25 per session. In advertisements for his appearances, he would often follow his name with [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]], [[Naturopathy|N.D.]], [[D.O.]] or [[Ph.D.]] Chicago was largely Springer's home base until the summer of 1934. After he applied for airtime on [[WGN-AM|WGN]] radio, the station contacted [[American Medical Association]]'s Bureau of Investigations for information regarding Springer. The AMA and [[Better Business Bureau]] quickly began to take note of his completely falsified education record. Before long, Springer had been labeled as a notorious fraud and doctor-impersonator by the medical community. An extensive article in the September 14, 1936 edition of ''[[Journal of the American Medical Association]]'' titled "Curtis Howe Springer: A [[Quackery|Quack]] and His Nostrums" detailed his exploits and lack of education.{{cite book |editor-first=Arthur Joseph |editor-last=Cramp |title=Nostrums and Quackery: Articles on the Nostrum Evil and Quackery Reprinted from the Journal of the American Medical Association, Volume 3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6P1DAAAAIAAJ&q=curtis+howe+springer&dq=curtis+howe+springer&hl=en&ei=UFiqTJa8IIu2sAOb-8HEAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBzgK|pages=162–164|publisher=American Medical Association Press|date=1936}} The book concluded that "a most thorough search fails to show that Springer was ever graduated by any reputable college or university, medical or otherwise." ===Radio career=== Although denied airtime on WGN, he was successful in obtaining a twice-daily slot as a [[radio evangelist]] on Chicago's [[WCFL (AM)|WCFL]]. He began broadcasting on the station in 1934. His programs were often an outlet for his support of [[Franklin Roosevelt]] and [[The New Deal]]. In addition, he would often use the radio show to sell his "[[Snake oil|medicines]]", including the [[antacid]] Re-Hib (confirmed by the American Medical Association to be mostly [[baking soda]]) and Antediluvian Tea ("a crude mixture of [[laxative]] herbs"). Around 1935, Springer left Chicago and began preaching on [[KDKA (AM)|KDKA]] in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]. === Health spas and Zzyzx === Springer's wife Mary encouraged him to try to launch a health spa and in 1931, he launched a resort called Haven of Rest in [[Fort Hill, Pennsylvania]]. Only six years after it first opened, he lost Haven of Rest due to [[tax evasion|non-payment of taxes]]. He attempted to set up other resorts and gatherings in [[Wilkes-Barre]], [[Johnstown, Pennsylvania|Johnstown]], and [[Mount Davis (Pennsylvania)|Mount Davis]] in Pennsylvania; [[Cumberland, Maryland]]; and [[Davenport, Iowa]]. [[File:SpringerSpaZzyzx.JPG|thumb|Remains of Springer's spa at Zzyzx, California.]] In 1944, Springer and his new [[fiancée]] Helen filed a [[Land claims|mining claim]] on federal land to 12,800 acres (51.8 km²) in [[California]]'s [[Mojave Desert]], claiming a tract about 8 miles (13 km) long and 3 miles (4.8 km) wide. The land contained the remains of an 1860 Army post and a railroad station on the defunct [[Tonopah and Tidewater Railroad]]. He named the settlement Zzyzx as a gimmick to ensure that it would be "the last word" in health. Zzyzx's original encampment consisted of 20 [[tent]]s, and he recruited [[homeless]] men from [[Los Angeles]]' [[Skid Row, Los Angeles|Skid Row]] to build simple concrete buildings. Springer created an imitation [[hot springs]] – which he attempted to pass off as genuine – by using a [[boiler]] to heat several [[heat sink|pool]]s.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=z0MIT1MnNMMC&pg=PA54&lpg=PA55&dq=Curtis+Howe+Springer | title = Weird California: Your Travel Guide to California's Local Legends and Best Kept Secrets | last = Greg | first = Bishop |author2=Joe Oesterle |author3=Mike Marinacci |author4=Mark Moran |author5=Mark Sceurman | pages = 54–55 | year = 2006 | publisher = [[Sterling Publishing Company, Inc.]] | location = [[New York, New York|New York]] | isbn = 978-1-4027-3384-0 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.knpr.org/archive/detailNew.cfm?FeatureID=1594|title=Zzyzx|work=[[KNPR]]|date=19 August 2004}} In time, Springer erected a sixty-room hotel, a church, a cross-shaped health spa with mineral baths, a radio broadcast studio, a private airstrip dubbed "Zyport" and several other buildings which included a castle. The "Boulevard of Dreams" was a divided parkway leading to an [[oasis]] on [[Lake Tuendae]], later identified as the habitat of the endangered [[Mohave chub]]. While building his retreat, he spent half the week in [[Los Angeles]], still recording his radio program, and rounding up workers to build his new resort by offering room and board at Zzyzx in exchange for labor. [[File:DesertStudiesCenterMainBuildingMarch2010.JPG|thumb|left|Administrative building and chapel built by Springer at Zzyzx, California. Now the [[Desert Studies Center]] headquarters.]] From Zzyzx, Springer continued his syndicated radio program, at one point carried by 221 stations in the United States and 102 more abroad, mixing religious music and his own [[radio evangelism]]. Along with this came his requests that listeners send him "donations" to get his special cures for everything from hair loss to cancer. The potions were actually little more than a blend of [[celery]], [[carrot]] and [[parsley]] juices. The Zzyzx Springs experience itself included goat milk; allegedly life-prolonging "[[Antediluvian|Antedeluvian]] Tea"; a $25, self-administered [[hemorrhoid]] cure; more solicitations for "donations"; and a twice-daily sermon over the loudspeakers. === Legal challenges and imprisonment === By the late 1960s, Springer had begun marking off lots on the land and allowing "donors" of large sums of money to his ministry to build homes on the lots. This caught the attention of federal officials. While Springer had posted mining claims in the area, under the [[General Mining Law of 1872]], it was still public land until such time that he validated the claims for patent by proving to federal government geologists that the claim contained minerals that could be extracted at a profit. The federal government took Springer to court claiming he was [[squatting]] on federal land. In 1974, he was found guilty of the charge. He offered to pay $34,187 in back rent on the land to the [[United States Bureau of Land Management|Bureau of Land Management]], but the government refused the payment and evicted him and his few hundred local followers. Springer was also convicted for making false claims that the health foods he sold would cure everything "from sore toes to [[cancer]]." He was represented in court by criminal attorney [[Gladys Root|Gladys Towles Root]]. In the trial, Springer was convicted of [[false advertising]]. He filed several appeals on this conviction, and two years later ended up serving 49 days of a 60-day sentence. Following the eviction, in 1976, the [[Bureau of Land Management]] allowed the [[California State University]] to manage the facilities and land in and around Zzyzx. A consortium of colleges combined funds and resources to convert the former resort into a research station called the [[Desert Studies Center]]; schools contributing to the center included California State Universities at [[Cal State Dominguez Hills|Dominguez Hills]], [[Cal State Fullerton|Fullerton]], [[Cal State Los Angeles|Los Angeles]], [[Cal State Long Beach|Long Beach]], [[California State Polytechnic University, Pomona|Pomona]] and [[Cal State Northridge|Northridge]].{{cite news|work=[[The Gadsden Times]] |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SKkfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NtYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2753,2588027&dq=zzyzx+curtis&hl=en |title=Zzyzx getting new lease on life|date=18 November 1976|page=11}} After his release from prison, Springer and his wife relocated to [[Las Vegas, Nevada]], where he spent the remainder of his life. == Death == Curtis Springer died in Las Vegas on August 19, 1985, at the age of 88. He was buried in the [[Riverside National Cemetery]] in [[Riverside, California]].{{FAG|3850932}} Two publications, the journal ''[[Word Ways: The Journal of Recreational Linguistics|Word Ways]]'' and the book ''[[Weird US|Weird California]]'', have incorrectly reported Springer's year of death as 1986. == See also == * [[Quackery]] * [[Squatting]] * [[Zzyzx, California]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Springer, Curtis Howe}} [[Category:1896 births]] [[Category:1985 deaths]] [[Category:American fraudsters]] [[Category:American radio personalities]] [[Category:American people convicted of fraud]] [[Category:Burials at Riverside National Cemetery]] [[Category:People from San Bernardino County, California]] [[Category:Religious broadcasting in the United States]] [[Category:Mojave Desert]] [[Category:Squatters]] [[Category:Quacks]]

revision.comment: Robot - Removing category Engineers who died in Nazi concentration camps per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 12]].
revision.text:
'''Daniel Mandl''' (April 20, 1891 – March 23, 1945) was a [[civil engineer]], [[inventor]], and a student of [[anthroposophy]].
== Life == Daniel Mandl was born in [[Prostějov]], [[Moravia]]. He studied engineering at the [[University of Vienna]], [[Austria]]. During [[World War I]], he commanded an [[artillery]] unit of the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]], and fought in [[Albania]]. A decorated officer, he resumed his studies after World War I. Upon graduation, he was employed by the General Electrical Company in [[Berlin]]. He was involved in the [[electrification]] of [[Slovakia]], and he introduced the then-new technology of [[arc welding]] to [[Czechoslovakia]], making improvements to arc welding [[electrodes]]. He was a student of [[anthroposophy]].
After the annexation of rump Czechoslovakia by Nazi Germany on March 15, 1939, Mandl held a teaching position in the Technical School founded by the [[Brno]] Jewish community. He was deported from [[Brno]] to the [[Theresienstadt concentration camp|Terezin]] ([[Theresienstadt]] [[ghetto]] on March 31, 1942, together with his wife Hajnalka and his son Tommy ([[Herbert Thomas Mandl]]). In Terezin, Mandl worked in the Jewish self-administration.<ref>[http://www.boerverlag.de/MANDL2.HTM Herbert Thomas Mandl's ''Die Wette des Philosophen'']</ref> He participated in the Jewish cultural life in the ghetto, delivering at least one lecture, titled "A Chapter from Some Thoughts On the History of Humanity," on June 23, 1944.<ref>[http://makarovainit.com/first.htm ''University over the Abyss'']</ref>
Mandl and his son were deported from [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]] to [[Auschwitz-Birkenau]] on September 28, 1944. Unbeknownst to his son Tommy at the time, Tommy was the only one selected for the transport but his father volunteered to go with him. From [[Auschwitz]], the Mandls were transported, in turn, to several [[Dachau concentration camp|Dachau]]-[[Kaufering concentration camp|Kaufering]] subcamps, where Mandl died March 23, 1945, a mere six weeks before the end of [[World War II]] (cf. testimonies of his son, Herbert Thomas Mandl).
==References== {{Reflist}} * Herbert Thomas Mandl: ''Erinnerungen an Daniel Mandl und Viktor Ullmann.'' in: Novalis 1997/98, Nr. 12/1 {{Anthroposophy series}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mandl, Daniel}} [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:Anthroposophists]] [[Category:Czech Jewish people who died in the Holocaust]] [[Category:Auschwitz concentration camp prisoners]] [[Category:Czech people who died in Dachau concentration camp]] [[Category:Czechoslovak civilians killed in World War II]] [[Category:Theresienstadt concentration camp prisoners]]
