revision.text:
{{Other uses|Mountain King (disambiguation){{!}}Mountain King}}
The '''King asleep in mountain''' (D 1960.2 in Stith Thompson's [[Motif (folkloristics)|motif index system]]){{sfnp|Ó hÓgáin|1991|p=197}} is a prominent [[folklore]] motif found in many [[Folklore|folktales]] and [[legend]]s. Thompson also termed it as the '''Kyffhäuser''' type.{{r|thompson}} Some other designations are: '''king in the mountain''', '''king under the mountain''', or '''sleeping hero'''.
Examples include the legends of [[Frederic Barbarossa]] at [[Kyffhäuser]], [[Prince Marko|Kraljević Marko]], [[Ogier the Dane]], [[King Arthur]], [[Charlemagne]], and [[King Matjaž]].{{sfnp|Ó hÓgáin|2000|p=92}}{{r|henken}}
The motifs A 571 "Culture hero asleep in mountain", and E 502, "The Sleeping Army" are similar and can occur in the same tale.{{sfnp|Ó hÓgáin|1991|p=197}} A related motif is the "Seven Sleepers" (D 1960.1,{{r|thompson}} also known as the "[[Rip Van Winkle]]" motif), whose type tale is the [[Seven Sleepers]] of [[Ephesus]] ([[Aarne-Thompson classification system|AT tale type]] 766).
== General features == [[File:Barbarossa01.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Frederick sends out the boy to see whether the ravens still fly.]]
King in the mountain stories involve legendary [[hero]]es, often accompanied by armed retainers, sleeping in remote dwellings, including caves on high mountaintops, remote islands, or supernatural worlds. The hero is frequently a historical figure of some [[military]] consequence in the history of the nation where the [[mountain]] is located.
The stories gathered by the [[Brothers Grimm]] concerning [[Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick Barbarossa]] and [[Charlemagne]] are typical of the stories told, and have been influential on many variants and subsequent adaptations. The presence of the hero is unsuspected, until some [[herder|herdsman]] wanders into the cave, typically looking for a lost animal, and sees the hero. The stories almost always mention the detail that the hero has grown a long beard, indicative of the long time he has slept beneath the mountain.
In the Brothers Grimm version, the hero speaks with the herdsman. Their conversation typically involves the hero asking, "Do the [[eagle]]s (or [[raven]]s) still circle the mountaintop?" The herdsman, or a mysterious voice, replies, "Yes, they still circle the mountaintop." "Then begone! My time has not yet come."
The herdsman in this story was then [[supernatural]]ly harmed by the experience: he ages rapidly, he emerges with his [[white hair|hair turned white]], and often he dies after repeating the tale. The story goes on to say that the king sleeps in the mountain, awaiting a summons to arise with his knights and defend the nation in a time of deadly peril. The [[omen]] that presages his rising will be the [[extinction]] of the [[bird]]s that trigger his awakening.<ref>[[Jacob Grimm|Jacob]] and [[Wilhelm Grimm]], ''Deutsche Sagen'' (1816/1818), no. 23.</ref><ref>[http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/grimm/sagen/g028.htm ''Kaiser Karl im Untersberg''] (German)</ref>
== Examples == A number of [[monarch|kings]], rulers, [[fictional character]]s and religious figures have become attached to this story. They include the following:
=== Religions === ==== Christianity ==== * St. [[John the Evangelist]] - according to the [[Golden Legend]], he is only sleeping in his grave at [[Ephesus]] until the coming of the [[Antichrist]], when he would be needed as a witness.<ref>[[Isidore of Seville]] – De ortu et obitu patrum (5th century)</ref><ref>[[Jacobus de Voragine]] – The Golden Legend</ref>{{dubious|At a first reading & text search, I cannot find such a legend at http://sourcebooks.fordham.edu/basis/goldenlegend/goldenlegend-volume4.asp - pls. more accurate source!|date=August 2016}}
==== Islam ==== * [[Muhammad al-Mahdi]] ([[Islamic mysticism]], especially [[Shi'a Islam|Shi'a]])
=== Asia (w/o Middle East) === ==== Japan ==== * [[Kūkai]], founder of [[Shingon Buddhism]]. He is said to be in deep meditation in a temple on [[Mount Kōya]], [[Wakayama Prefecture]], awaiting the coming of [[Maitreya]], the next [[Buddhahood|Buddha]].
==== Philippines ==== * [[Bernardo Carpio]], the "King of the [[Tagalog people|Tagalogs]]", is said to be trapped in the mountains of [[Rodriguez, Rizal]], east of [[Metro Manila]] on [[Luzon]]. Legend has it that Carpio, a man of superhuman strength, causes earthquakes as he struggles to break free of his chains.
=== Europe === ==== Armenia ==== * Mher<ref>[http://www.hums.canterbury.ac.nz/clas/ejms/out_of_print/JMSv1n2/JMSv1n2Boyle.pdf Mher in the Carved Rock], J. A. Boyle, at the Library of the University of Canterbury, [[Christchurch]], New Zealand</ref>
==== Baltic states ==== * A popular motif in [[Latvia]]n legends involves a castle sinking into ground leaving a hill behind it. Years later somebody finds a way into the hill and somehow guesses the name of the castle causing it to rise again and its ruler and his people to return to the living. * [[Vytautas the Great]] (Lithuania). It is believed he will rise from his grave when the worst danger threatens Lithuania in order to defend the motherland at the last battle.
==== Britain and Ireland ==== * [[King Arthur]] ([[Great Britain]] and [[Brittany]]), perhaps the most famous of the "king under the mountain" examples. According to the legend, Arthur was taken away to [[Avalon]] to sleep until he was needed by the people of Britain. Several legends talk of a herdsman who stumbles across a cave on mainland Britain, wherein he finds Arthur sleeping, often with his knights and [[Excalibur]] by his side. In a variation on this, sometimes the exploring herdsman finds instead just Arthur's knights, or [[Sir Lancelot]], [[Guinevere]] and the knights sleeping in wait on the return of the "Once and Future King". * [[Merlin (wizard)|Merlin]] of the [[Arthurian Cycle|Arthurian legend]], who is imprisoned in an oak tree by [[Nimue]]. * [[Thomas the Rhymer]] is found under a hill with a retinue of knights in a tale from [[Anglo-Scottish border]]. Likewise, [[Harry Hotspur]] was said to have been hunting in the [[Cheviots]] when he and his hounds got holed-up in the Hen Hole (or ''"Hell-hole"'') awaiting the sound of a hunting horn to awaken them from their slumber. Another [[Anglo-Scottish border|border]] variant concerns a party of huntsmen who chase a [[Roe Deer|roebuck]] into the Cheviots when they heard the sweetest music playing from the Henhole, however when they entered they became lost and are trapped to this day.<ref>Henry Tegner; ''Ghosts of The North Country'', 1991 Butler Publishing, {{ISBN|0-946928-40-1}}. p.13</ref>
===== Wales ===== * [[Bran the Blessed]] * [[Owain Lawgoch]], Welsh soldier and nobleman (14th century) * [[Owain Glyndŵr]], the last native born Welshman to hold the title "Prince of Wales"; he disappeared after a long but ultimately unsuccessful rebellion against the English. He was never captured or betrayed and refused all Royal pardons. * An unnamed [[giant (mythology)|giant]] is supposed to sleep in [[Plynlimon]].
===== Ireland ===== * [[Fionn mac Cumhaill]] is said to sleep in a cave/mountain surrounded by the Fianna (he is differentiated from them because of his large stature). It is told that the day will come when the Dord Fiann is sounded three times and Fionn and the [[Fianna]] will rise up again, as strong and well as they ever were. In other accounts he will return to glory as a great hero of Ireland.<ref>[[Augusta, Lady Gregory]] – Gods and Fighting Men (1904)</ref> * [[Gerald FitzGerald, 3rd Earl of Desmond|Gearóid Iarla]], Earl of Desmond, who dozes under Lough Gur with his silver-shod horse{{sfnp|Ó hÓgáin|2000|p=92}} * [[Gerald FitzGerald, 8th Earl of Kildare]], who is at temporary rest under the [[Curragh of Kildare]]{{sfnp|Ó hÓgáin|2000|p=92}}
===== England ===== * [[Harold Godwinson|King Harold]]. In Anglo-Saxon legends he has not been slain at Senlac, to come one day to liberate the English from the [[Norman yoke]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lkqIalGZwZgC&pg=PA143&dq=Harold+not+slain+at+Senlac&hl=pt-PT&sa=X&ei=O7QtT7fXNKOi0QXSzpCtCA&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Harold%20not%20slain%20at%20Senlac&f=false The Science of Fairy Tales: An Enquiry Into Fairy Mythology], [[Edwin Sidney Hartland]], 1925 edition, p. 143</ref> * [[Sir Francis Drake]]. It is stated that when England is in deadly peril, if [[Drake's Drum]] is beaten, then Sir Francis Drake will arise to defend England from the sea. According to the legend, it can be heard to beat at times when England is at war or significant national events take place.
==== German-speaking realm ==== * [https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Bergentrückung Bergentrückung,] Literally meaning [[mountain]] [[rapture]], is a prominent motif in [[folklore]] and [[mythology]] referring to the king in the mountain. * [[Charlemagne]], Emperor of future Germany, France, and the Low Countries, rests in the [[Untersberg]] near Salzburg. ([[Austria]]) * [[Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick Barbarossa]], Holy Roman Emperor, sleeps in the [[Kyffhäuser]] mountain and will rise to save the Empire. ([[Germany]]) * [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor]] * [[Henry the Fowler]], King. (Germany)
==== Greek, Hellenistic and Byzantine ==== ===== Ancient Greece ===== * [[Theseus]] ([[Athens]]) * [[Typhon]] and [[Enceladus (giant)|Enceladus]] in [[Mount Etna]]
===== Byzantine Empire ===== * [[Constantine I]], said to have been turned into a stone statue, although not resting within a mountain. * [[Constantine XI Palaiologos]], the last emperor of the [[Eastern Roman Empire]], said to have been turned into marble and thus was known as "Marmaromenos", "the Marble King". He was said to be hidden somewhere underground until his glorious return as the Immortal Emperor. * [[John III Doukas Vatatzes]] (also known as "Kaloyannis III'")
==== Hungarians ==== * [[Prince Csaba|Csaba]], the son of [[Attila the Hun]] who is supposed to ride down the [[Milky Way]] when the [[Székelys]] are threatened. * [[Stephen I of Hungary|King St. Stephen]], [[Ladislaus I of Hungary|King St. Ladislaus]], [[Matthias Corvinus of Hungary|King Matthias Corvinus]]
==== Iberia ==== * [[Boabdil]], last Islamic prince of Granada. (Spain)<ref>Ellen M. Dolan, Sue D. Royals, ''Building Comprehension - Grade 5'', p. 29. Milliken Publishing, 1999, {{ISBN|978-0787703943}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=iaTS6OQ7pKAC&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=%22Boabdil%22+%22legend%22&source=bl&ots=Xb6m07VAuD&sig=FuUhRpHqE-gegWO6wM3vb97lOrQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjfmcHWpaXOAhXLVRoKHYYIA_wQ6AEIRTAG#v=onepage&q=%22Boabdil%22%20%22legend%22&f=false]</ref> * [[King Pelayo]], Visigothic king of Asturia, credited with beginning the Reconquista. (Spain) * [[Roderic|King Rodrigo]] (Spain). Said to escape from the Moorish invasion and await for "the time of maximum need" to save his people. [[File:Alonso Sánchez Coello 009.jpg|thumb|right|Sebastian I. With his death, the house of Aviz lost the throne of Portugal. Sebastianists hold that he will return to rule Portugal's Fifth Empire.]] * [[Sebastian I of Portugal|Sebastian I]] of [[Portugal]]. It is said by [[Sebastianism|Sebastianists]] that the king will return in a hazy morning in time of need.
==== Jewish Ashkenazi ==== * [[Golem of Prague]], whose remains are said to be in the attic of the [[Old New Synagogue]] in [[Prague]], and that it can be brought back to defend the Jewish people. ([[Jewish mysticism]]) * [[King David]] is depicted in [[Haim Nachman Bialik]]'s tale ''"King David in the Cave"'' as sleeping along with his warriors deep inside a cave, waiting for the blast of the ram's horn that will awaken them from their millennia of slumber and arouse them to redeem Israel.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/alabasters_archive/canaanism_solutions.html "Canaanism:" Solutions and Problems] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120717024232/http://members.tripod.com/alabasters_archive/canaanism_solutions.html |date=2012-07-17 }}, Boas Evron, Alabaster's Archive</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.benyehuda.org/bialik/veyehi_hayom_hamelex_david_bameara.html|title=הַמֶּלֶךְ דָּוִד בַּמְּעָרָה / ח"נ ביאליק|website=www.benyehuda.org}}</ref> This role was not attributed to King David in earlier Jewish tradition.
==== Romania ==== * [[Vlad III the Impaler]]
==== Scandinavia ==== [[File:Holger danske.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Statue of Ogier the Dane, [[Kronborg Castle]]]] * [[Ogier the Dane]] ({{lang-da|Holger Danske}}, [[Denmark]]) * [[Olaf I of Norway|King Olaf I]] ([[Norway]]) * [[Väinämöinen]], the protagonist of the [[Finland|Finnish]] national epic [[Kalevala]]. At the end of Kalevala, he leaves on a boat, promising to return when he is most needed. * [[Knights of Ålleberg]] ([[Sweden]])
==== Slavic nations ==== ===== East Slavic ===== * [[Alexander Suvorov]] ([[Russia]]), Russian generalissimo, sleeps in a deep cave where prayer is heard and icon lamp burns. The legend says Suvorov will come back to save his country from a mortal danger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pravoslavie.ru/jurnal/28069.htm|title=Елена Лебедева. Русский архистратиг / Православие.Ru|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Taras Shevchenko]], Ukrainian poet and painter ([[Ukraine]]), believed to be a supernatural hero (''charakternik''), is said to sleep under his grave mound in [[Kanev]] or even in the [[Kiev Pechersk Lavra]].
===== South Slavic ===== * [[Prince Marko|Marko Kraljević]] ([[Serbia]]) * [[Matija Gubec]] ([[Croatia]]) * [[Kralj Matjaž]] ([[Slovenia]]) * [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] was considered to be also not dead but in [[Irkutsk]] and to come back by a sect from [[Slavonia]], [[Croatia]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lkqIalGZwZgC&pg=PA144&dq=Bishop+Melchisedech+of+Roumania+Slavonic+sect+Napoleon&hl=pt-PT&sa=X&ei=qrYtT_CHFIfL0QXjqeStCA&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Bishop%20Melchisedech%20of%20Roumania%20Slavonic%20sect%20Napoleon&f=false The Science of Fairy Tales: An Enquiry Into Fairy Mythology], [[Edwin Sidney Hartland]], 1925 edition, p. 144</ref>
===== West Slavic ===== * Ječmínek, legendary [[Moravia]]n king will, according to a prophecy, return to save his country from enemies.<ref name="Old Bohemian Legends 1894">[[Alois Jirásek]], Old Bohemian Legends (1894, Staré pověsti české)</ref> *[[Giewont]], a [[mountain]] [[massif]] which is said to be a sleeping knight ([[Poland]]) * [[St. Wenceslas]] (Václav) of [[Bohemia]] ([[Czech Republic]]). He sleeps in the [[Blaník]] mountain (with a huge army of Czech knights) and will emerge to protect his country at its worst time, riding on his white [[horse]] and wielding the legendary hero Bruncvík's sword.<ref name="Old Bohemian Legends 1894"/> * Knights of Sitno in Slovak mythology are a legion of knights supposedly sleeping inside the mountain Sitno in Central [[Slovakia]], waiting to be called upon in times when the Slovaks are in danger. It is said that every seven years, the oldest of them climbs up the hill and shouts the question: "Is it time yet?" in every world direction. If nobody answers, he climbs back inside.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://sitnoholding.sitnobusiness.com/en/the-legend/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-06-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606215808/http://sitnoholding.sitnobusiness.com/en/the-legend/ |archive-date=2014-06-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==== Switzerland ==== * [[William Tell]] ([[Switzerland]], in some legends accompanied by [[William Tell#The Three Tells|two other Tells]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/sleep.html#Tells|title=Sleeping Hero Legends|website=Pitt.edu|accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref>)
=== Middle East === ==== Persia ==== * [[Kai Khosrow|Key-Khosrow]], legendary shah of [[Persia]].
=== North America === * The [[Puebloan peoples|Pueblo]] hero-god [[Montezuma (mythology)|Montezuma]] — believed to have been a divine king in prehistoric times, and suspended in an Arizona mountain that bears his image. * [[Ute Mountain|The Sleeping Ute]] mountain in Colorado is said to have been a "Great Warrior God" who fell asleep while recovering from wounds received in a great battle with "the Evil Ones" (there are many other variants of this legend) * [[Tecumseh]] of the [[Shawnee]] * [[Emperor Norton]] is claimed by several defunct civil rights groups to have been destined to return to the USA when the unity of the Republic is at its nadir.<ref>''A gay court pays homage to its queer emperor / Group attends 31st-annual memorial service'' [http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/COLMA-A-gay-court-pays-homage-to-its-queer-2697341.php]</ref>
== Sleeping anti-hero and villain == Sometimes this type of story or archetype is also attached to not-so-heroic figures, who are either simple anti-heroes or fully villains, whose return would mean the end of the world, or whose sleep represents something positive. This kind of archetype is known as the "Chained Satan" archetype.<ref name="Mher in the Carved Rock">{{cite web|url=http://www.hums.canterbury.ac.nz/clas/ejms/out_of_print/JMSv1n2/JMSv1n2Boyle.pdf|title=School of Humanities and Creative Arts - University of Canterbury|website=The University of Canterbury|accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref> Among examples of this are: * The [[Sleeping Giant (Connecticut)|Sleeping Giant]] mountain in [[Connecticut]], United States was said by the local [[Quinnipiac]] Indians to be the demon Hobbomock, sealed by the Great Spirit. One day he would supposedly awaken and destroy the world. * [[Artavasdes II of Armenia]], who according to [[Moses of Chorene]] was chained and cursed to stay eternally chained by his father [[Artaxias II]].<ref name="Mher in the Carved Rock"/> * [[Loki]] in [[Norse mythology]] was bound by the gods after he engineered the death of [[Baldr]]. With the onset of [[Ragnarök]], Loki is foretold to set free and fight alongside the forces of the [[Jötunn|jötnar]] against the [[Norse gods|gods]]. * [[Dukljan]] ([[Serbian mythology]])
== See also == {{Portal|Folklore}} * [[Honi HaM'agel]] * [[King Arthur's messianic return]] * [[Rip Van Winkle]] * [[Seven Sleepers]] * [[Sidhe]] * [[Stasis (fiction)|Stasis]] * [[Suspended animation]]
== References == {{Reflist|refs= <ref name=henken> {{citation|last=Henken |first=Elissa R. |title=National Redeemer: Owain Glyndŵr in Welsh Tradition |publisher=Cornell University Press |year=1996 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WpDJObx8lpMC&pg=PA83 |page=83}} </ref>
<ref name=thompson> {{citation|last=Thompson |first=Stith |title=The Folktale |publisher=University of California Press |year=1977 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIuLBDOUc80C&pg=PA85 |pages=264–265}} </ref> }}
== Bibliography == {{Refbegin}} * {{citation|last=Ó hÓgáin |first=Dáithí |title=Has the Time Come?' (MLSIT 8009): The Barbarossa Legend in Ireland and Its Historical Background |journal=Béaloideas |volume=59 <!--The Fairy Hill Is on Fire! Proceedings of the Symposium on theSupernatural in Irish and Scottish Migratory Legends--> |year=1991 |pages=197–207 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KEcsAQAAIAAJ&q=%221960.2%22}} {{jstor|20522387}} * {{citation|last=Ó hÓgáin |first=Dáithí |title=The Importance of Folklore within the European Heritage: Some Remarks |journal=Béaloideas |volume=68 |year=2000 |pages=67–98 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vxvaAAAAMAAJ}} {{jstor|20522558}} {{Refend}}
== External links == * [http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/sleep.html List of other sleeping hero legends]
{{DEFAULTSORT:King In The Mountain}} [[Category:Legendary rulers]] [[Category:Medieval legends]] [[Category:Comparative mythology]] [[Category:Sleeping heroes| ]]

revision.comment: /* Personal life */ Tagging added death date of father as [[WP:CITENEED]]
revision.text:
{{for|Kunal Kapoor who acted in the popular film [[Rang De Basanti]]|Kunal Kapoor}} {{pp-pc1}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=February 2016}} {{BLP sources|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Kunal Kapoor | image = Sanjana Kapoor Kunal Kapoor Abhishek Bachchan.jpg | image_size = 245px | caption = Kunal Kapoor (2nd from right) with sister [[Sanjana Kapoor]], daughter Shaira Laura Kapoor and [[Abhishek Bachchan]], in 2015 | birthname = | parents = [[Shashi Kapoor]]{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/shashi-kapoors-son-kunal-kapoor-returns-to-acting-with-akshay-kumars-singh-is-bliing/|title=Kunal Kapoor returns to acting|date=26 June 2015|accessdate=4 July 2015|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}
[[Jennifer Kendal]] | relatives = See [[Kapoor Family]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|6|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bombay]], [[Bombay State]], [[India]] | residence = | years_active = | children = | height = | spouse = | occupation = Actor, ad film producer and director }} '''Kunal Kapoor''' (born 26 June 1959),[http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/meet-the-shashi-kapoor-no-one-knows/20150422.htm Meet the Shashi Kapoor no one knew], [[Rediff]] son of the late actors [[Shashi Kapoor]] and [[Jennifer Kendal]], is an Indian film actor who made his debut with the 1972 English-language film ''[[Siddhartha (film)|Siddhartha]]'', later acted in [[Shyam Benegal]]'s ''[[Junoon (1978 film)|Junoon]]'' and in his first mainstream Bollywood film, ''[[Ahista Ahista (1981 film)|Ahista]]'', opposite [[Padmini Kolhapure]] as well as ''[[Vijeta (1982 film)|Vijeta]]''. He also acted in the art films ''[[Utsav]]'' (1984) and ''[[Trikal]]'' (1985).{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/shashi-kapoors-son-kunal-kapoor-returns-to-acting-with-akshay-kumars-singh-is-bliing/|title=Kunal Kapoor returns to acting|date=26 June 2015|accessdate=4 July 2015|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}} In 1987, he stopped acting after ''Trikal'' to set up his own company, Adfilm-Valas, to producing and direct television commercials. Adfilm Valas has also [[line producer|line-produced]] for many international feature films and ad films shot in India. Notably, the credit sequence of the film ''[[City of Joy]]'', and the French films ''[[w:fr:Le Cactus|Le Cactus]]'' (2005) and ''Fire in Paradise''. In 2015, he returned to films after 30 years, appearing in ''[[Singh is Bling]]'' as [[Amy Jackson]]'s father. ==Personal life== Kunal Kapoor was born into the famous first family of [[Bollywood]], the [[Kapoor family]], the eldest child of [[Shashi Kapoor]] and his British theater-actress wife [[Jennifer Kendal|Jennifer Kapoor]]. His paternal grandfather, [[Prithviraj Kapoor]], was a doyen of the theatre, a pioneer of the Indian film industry and the progenitor of the famous [[Kapoor family]]. His maternal grandfather, [[Geoffrey Kendal]], was a British theatre personality. Kapoor's mother, Jennifer, died of cancer in 1984, while his father, Shashi Kapoor, died in December 2017.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Kapoor's siblings are [[Karan Kapoor]] (b. 18 January 1962) and [[Sanjana Kapoor]] (b. 27 November 1967). Karan, a popular model who also worked in a few films in the 1980s, now runs a photography business in the UK. [[Sanjana Kapoor]] runs the ancestral [[Prithvi Theatre]] and is married to [[Valmik Thapar]], a noted conservationist. Kunal was married to filmmaker [[Ramesh Sippy]]'s daughter Sheena, who is a well-known photographer. They had two children together, a son named Zahan Prithviraj Kapoor, and a daughter named Shaira Kapoor. Kunal and Sheena are now divorced.[http://www.news18.com/photogallery/movies/in-pics-meet-shashi-kapoors-family-992937-10.html Meet the Kapoors], [[Network 18]]. ==Filmography== ===Actor=== {|class="wikitable" |- !Year !! Film !!Role!!Notes |- |1972 |''[[Siddhartha (film)|Siddhartha]]'' |Siddhartha's son |[[English language|English]] film |- |[[Bollywood films of 1978|1978]] |''[[Junoon (1978 film)|Junoon]]'' | | |- |[[Bollywood films of 1981|1981]] |''[[Ahista Ahista (1981 film)|Ahista Ahista]]'' |Kunal | |- |[[Bollywood films of 1982|1982]] |''[[Vijeta (1982 film)|Vijeta]]'' |Angad | |- |[[Bollywood films of 1984|1984]] |''[[Utsav]]'' |Aryak | |- |[[Bollywood films of 1985|1985]] |''[[Trikal]]'' |Kapitan Ribeiro/ Governor | |- |[[Bollywood films of 2015|2015]] |''[[Singh is Bling]]'' |[[Amy Jackson]]'s father | |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{IMDb name|0004431}} {{Kapoor family}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kapoor, Kunal}} [[Category:Indian male film actors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors in Hindi cinema]] [[Category:Kapoor family|Kunal]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Anglo-Indian people]]
