{{Infobox cricketer | name = Mamata Thapa
ममता थापा | image = | country = Nepal | fullname = Mamata Thapa | nickname = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|09|13|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Kingdom of Nepal|Nepal]] | heightft = | heightinch = | heightm = | batting = Right-hand bat | bowling = | role = [[Wicketkeeper]] | international = true | T20Idebutdate = 17 November | T20Idebutyear = 2010 | T20Idebutagainst = Japan | T20Icap = 10 | lastT20Idate = 24 September | lastT20Iyear = 2014 | lastT20Iagainst = Bangladesh }} '''Mamata Thapa''' ({{lang-ne|ममता थापा}}; born 13 September 1991) is a [[Nepal]]ese wicketkeeper and Right-hand bat woman of Nepali National Cricket team.{{cite web | url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/player/302104.html | title=Mamta Thapa Nepal | work=espncricinfo.com | accessdate=25 June 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thapa, Mamata}} [[Category:Nepalese people]] [[Category:1991 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Nepalese women cricketers]] [[Category:Nepalese wicket-keepers]] [[Category:Cricketers at the 2010 Asian Games]] [[Category:Cricketers at the 2014 Asian Games]]

:''For the 15th-century papal legate, see [[Onofrio de Santa Croce]].'' {{Infobox saint |name=Saint Onuphrius
Ὀνούφριος |birth_date=unknown |death_date=4th or 5th century |feast_day=June 12 |venerated_in=[[Roman Catholic Church]]
[[Eastern Orthodox Churches]]
[[Oriental Orthodox Churches]]
[[Eastern Catholic Churches]] |image=OnuphriusByzantineIcon4thCentury.jpg |imagesize=200px |caption=Icon of Onuphrius. Provenance and date unknown. |birth_place= |death_place= |titles=Hermit |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes=old hermit dressed only in long hair and a loincloth of leaves; hermit with an angel bringing him the Eucharist or bread; hermit with a crown at his feet[http://saints.sqpn.com/sainto14.htm Patron Saints Index: Saint Onuphrius] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080804031426/http://saints.sqpn.com/sainto14.htm |date=2008-08-04 }} |patronage=weavers; jurists[http://www.luederhniemeyer.com/prints/15267_e.php lüder h niemeyer: Cornelis Cort, Saint Onuphrius with the Rosary] [[Centrache]], [[Italy]] |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= |prayer= |prayer_attrib= }} '''Onuphrius''' or '''Onoufrios''' ({{lang-el|Ὀνούφριος}}), venerated as '''Saint Onuphrius''' in both the [[Roman Catholic Church]] and [[Eastern Catholic Church]]es; '''Venerable Onuphrius''' in [[Eastern Orthodoxy]] and '''Saint Nofer the Anchorite''' in [[Oriental Orthodoxy]], lived as a [[hermit]] in the desert of [[Upper Egypt]] in the 4th or 5th centuries.{{sfn|Butler, p.94}} ==Life and legends== Onophrius was one of the [[Desert Fathers]] who made a great impression on Eastern spirituality in the third and fourth centuries, around the time that Christianity was emerging as the dominant faith of the Roman Empire. At this time many Christians were inspired to go out into the desert and live in prayer in the harsh environment of extreme heat and cold, with little to eat and drink, surrounded by all sorts of dangerous animals and robbers. It is uncertain in which century Onuphrius lived; the account of [[Paphnutius the Ascetic]], who encountered him in the Egyptian desert, forms the sole source for our knowledge of the life of Saint Onuphrius.{{sfn|Butler, p.94}} Even the authorship is uncertain; "Paphnutius", a common name of Egyptian origin in the [[Thebaid|Upper Thebaid]], may refer to Paphnutius of Scetis, a 4th-century abbot of [[Lower Egypt]], rather than Paphnutius the Ascetic.{{sfn|Butler, pp.95-96}} "But Paphnutius the Great [i.e. Paphnutius the Ascetic]," [[Alban Butler]] writes, "also had a number of stories to tell of visions and miraculous happenings in the desert, some of them in much the same vein as the story of Onuphrius."{{sfn|Butler, pp.95-96}} The name Onuphrius is thought to be a Hellenized form of a [[Copts|Coptic]] name ''Unnufer'', ultimately from the [[Egyptian language|Egyptian]]: ''[[:wikt:wnn-nfr|wnn-nfr]]'' meaning "perfect one", or "he who is continually good", an epithet of the god [[Osiris]].{{cite journal |title = The Egyptian Origin of Some English Personal Names |last = Gardiner |first = Alan H. |journal = [[Journal of the American Oriental Society]] |issn = 0003-0279 |volume = 56 |issue = 2 |year = 1936 |pages = 189–97 |doi = 10.2307/594666 |jstor = 594666 |via = [[JSTOR]] |registration = y |bibcode = 1964JAOS...84..128H }} A tradition, not found in Paphnutius' account, states that Onuphrius had studied [[jurisprudence]] and [[philosophy]] before becoming a monk near [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]] and then a hermit. According to Paphnutius’s account, Paphnutius undertook a pilgrimage to study the hermits’ way of life and to determine whether it was for him. Wandering in the desert for 16 days, on the 17th day, Paphnutius came across a wild figure covered in hair, wearing a loincloth of leaves. Frightened, Paphnutius ran away, up a mountain, but the figure called him back, shouting, “Come down to me, man of God, for I am a man also, dwelling in the desert for the love of God.”{{sfn|Butler, p.94}} [[Image:Kidron jerusalem (10533).jpg|thumb|250px|Stone carving above the entrance of the Onuphrius monastery in [[Akeldama]], Jerusalem (Potter's field). The image shows Onuphrius bowing down to an angel. Notable features are his long beard and leaf loincloth.]] Turning back, Paphnutius talked to the wild figure, who introduced himself as Onuphrius and explained that he had once been a monk at a large monastery in the Thebaid but who had now lived as a hermit for 70 years, enduring extreme thirst, hunger, and discomforts. He said that it was his guardian angel who had brought him to this desolate place. Onuphrius took Paphnutius to his cell, and they spoke until sunset, when bread and water miraculously appeared outside of the hermit's cell.{{sfn|Butler, p.94}} They spent the night in the prayer, and in the morning Paphnutius discovered that Onuphrius was near death. Paphnutius, distressed, asked the hermit if he should occupy Onuphrius’ cell after the hermit’s death, but Onuphrius told him, "That may not be, thy work is in Egypt with thy brethren."{{sfn|Butler, p.94}} Onuphrius asked Paphnutius for there to be a memorial with incense in Egypt in remembrance of the hermit. He then blessed the traveler and died.{{sfn|Butler, p.94}} Due to the hard and rocky ground, Paphnutius could not dig a hole for a grave, and therefore covered Onuphrius’ body in a cloak, leaving the hermit’s body in a cleft of the rocks. After the burial, Onuphrius’ cell crumbled, which Paphnutius took to be a sign that he should not stay.{{sfn|Butler, p.94}} One scholar has written that Onuphrius’ life "fits the mold of countless desert hermits or anchorites... [However] despite its predictability, Paphnutius' ''Life of Onuphrius'' is marked by several unique details... the years of Onuphrius' youth were passed in a monastery that observed the rule of strict silence; a [[Red Deer|hind]] instructed him in Christian rites and liturgy. During his sixty years in the desert, Onuphrius' only visitor was an angel who delivered a [[Sacramental bread|Host]] every Sunday..."Peter W. Parshall; Rainer Schoch, National Gallery of Art (U.S.); ''Origins of European Printmaking'' (Yale University Press, 2005), 318. ==Veneration== [[Image:Saint onuphre.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Onuphrius depicted as a "wild man".]] Both the Eastern Orthodox and Catholic Churches traditionally mark his [[feast day]] on [[June 12 (Orthodox Liturgics)|12 June]].[https://oca.org/saints/lives/2000/06/12/107799-venerable-onuphrius-the-great "Venerable Onuphrius the Great", Orthodox Church in America] A ''Life'' of Onuphrius of later Greek origin states that the saint died on June 11; however, his feast day was celebrated on June 12 in the Eastern Orthodox calendars from an early date. The legend of Saint Onuphrius was depicted in [[Pisa|Pisa's]] camposanto (monumental cemetery), and in [[Rome]], a church, [[Sant'Onofrio (Rome)|Sant'Onofrio]], was built in his honor on the [[Janiculan Hill]] in the fifteenth century.{{sfn|Butler, p.96}} Antony, the [[archbishop of Novgorod]], writing around 1200 AD, stated that Onuphrius’ head was conserved in the church of Saint Acindinus (Akindinos) ([[Constantinople]]).{{Cite web|url=http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/56850|title=Sant' Onofrio su santiebeati.it|website=Santiebeati.it|access-date=2018-03-17}} For several decades Orthodox seminarians in Poland have begun their spiritual training in the monastery of St. Onuphrius in Jablechna. It is said that the saint himself chose the place for it, appearing nearly four hundred years ago to fishermen and leaving them an Icon of himself on the banks of the river Buh.[http://www.ukrainian-orthodoxy.org/saints/beauty/OnuphriusEng.htm "Venerable Onuphrius the Great", Ukrainian Orthodoxy] There is a monastery in [[Jerusalem]] dedicated to him. The monastery is located at the far end of Gai Ben Hinnom, the [[Gehenna]] valley of hell, further it is situated within the site of a Jewish Second Temple cemetery and is built among and includes many typical burial niches common to that period. The monastery also marks the location of Hakeldama, the purported place where Judas Iscariot hanged himself. Saint Onuphrius was venerated in [[Munich]], [[Basel]], and southern [[Germany]], and the Basel [[Renaissance Humanism|humanist]] [[Sebastian Brant]] (who named his own son OnuphriusPeter W. Parshall; Rainer Schoch, National Gallery of Art (U.S.); ''Origins of European Printmaking'' (Yale University Press, 2005), 319.) published a broadside named ''In Praise of the Divine Onuphrius and Other Desert Hermit Saints''. Onuphrius was depicted in a 1520 painting by [[Hans Schäufelein]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.bridgemanartondemand.com/art/205761/St_Onuphrius_c1520|title=Art.com - Bridgeman Collection|website=www.bridgemanartondemand.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-17}} ===Art=== [[File:Battistello Caracciolo - St Onophrius - WGA04067.jpg|thumb|left|[[Battistello Caracciolo]], Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Rome]] [[Image:Yilanli (Snake) Church.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Fresco of Onuphrius (on left) in the [[Snake Church]].]] Images of Saint Onuphrius were conflated with those of the medieval “[[wild man]]".[http://www.nga.gov/press/exh/206/index.htm National Gallery of Art | Press Office] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080830070851/http://www.nga.gov/press/exh/206/index.htm |date=2008-08-30 }} In art, he is depicted as a wild man completely covered with hair, wearing a girdle of leaves.{{sfn|Butler, p.96}} He is depicted at [[Snake Church]] (''Yilanlı Kilise'') in the [[Churches of Göreme, Turkey|Göreme valley open-air museum]] in [[Cappadocia]], [[Turkey]].[http://www.nevsehir.gov.tr/ing_nevsehir_detay.php?id=79 T.C. Nevşehir Valiliği]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He became the [[patron saint]] of weavers due to the fact that he was depicted "dressed only in his own abundant hair, and a loin-cloth of leaves". He (S. Onofrio) was named co-saint patron of the city of [https://web.archive.org/web/20120328113921/http://www.santonofrio.com/home.htm Palermo] in 1650. ===Name variants=== His name appears very variously as '''Onuphrius''', '''Onouphrius''', '''Onofrius'''; and in different languages as '''Onofre''' (Portuguese, Spanish), '''[[Onofrio]]''' (Italian), etc. In [[Arabic]], the saint was known as ''Abū Nufir'' ({{lang-ar|ابو نفر}}) or as ''Nofer'' ({{lang-ar|نوفر}}), which, besides being a variant of the name Onuphrius, also means "herbivore." Onuphrius and Onofrio are sometimes Anglicized as '''[[wikt:Humphrey|Humphrey]]''', an unrelated name that is usually given a [[Germanic name|Germanic]] etymology. ===Folklore=== Sicilians pray to Saint Onuphrius when they have lost something. The prayer has many variants but it generally mentions the miraculous properties of Saint Onuphrius' hair . It is widely accepted that repeating the prayer whilst looking for something like keys, a misplaced ring or anything else, will greatly help in finding it sooner.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} ==See also== {{commons category}} * [[San Onofre (disambiguation)|San Onofre]] * [[Venerable]] *[[Hermit]] ==Notes== ==Sources== *Alban Butler, Paul Burns; ''Butler’s Lives of the Saints'' (Continuum International Publishing Group, 2000) ==External links== *{{it icon}} [http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/56850 Sant’Onofrio] *{{sp icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20080802140320/http://sanonofre.info/ San Onofre] *{{sp icon}} [http://www.san-onofre.com.ar San Onofre] * [http://www.colecciondeverda.com/2012/11/san-onofre.html Saint Onuphrius engraved by a Flemish artist from the De Verda collection] *[http://cdm16028.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/105863/rec/1 The Wild Man: Medieval Myth and Symbolism], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on Onuphrius (no. 20) {{Authority control}} {{Coptic saints}} [[Category:4th-century deaths]] [[Category:Saints from Roman Egypt]] [[Category:Egyptian hermits]] [[Category:4th-century Christian saints]] [[Category:Angelic visionaries]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Coptic Orthodox saints]] [[Category:Coptic Christians]] [[Category:Egyptian saints]] [[Category:Egyptian Christian saints]] [[Category:Copts]]

{{for|the British diplomat|Robert Macaire (diplomat)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} '''Robert Macaire''' is a fictional character, an unscrupulous swindler, who appears in a number of French plays, films, and other works of art. In French culture he represents an archetypal villain. He was principally the creation of an actor, [[Frédérick Lemaître]], who took the stock figure of "a ragged tramp, a common thief with tattered frock coat patched pants" and transformed him during his performances into "the dapper confidence man, the financial schemer, the juggler of joint-stock companies" that could serve to lampoon financial speculation and government corruption.<ref name=ramus>{{cite book|last1=Ramus|first1=Charles F.|title=Daumier, 120 Great Lithographs |date=1978|publisher=Dover Publications|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2XB2JrB-cnMC&pg=PR15&|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
Playwright [[Benjamin Antier]] (1787–1870), with two collaborators [[Saint-Amand (writer)|Saint-Amand]] and [[Polyanthe]], created the character Robert Macaire in the play ''l'Auberge des Adrets'', a serious-minded melodrama. After the work's failure at its 1823 premiere, [[Frédérick Lemaître]] played the role as a comic figure instead. Violating all the conventions of its genre, it became a comic success and ran for a hundred performances. The transformation violated social standards that demanded crime be treated with seriousness and expected criminals to be punished appropriately. The play was soon banned, and representations of the character of Macaire were banned time and again until the 1880s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=McCormick|first1=John|title=Popular Theatres of Nineteenth Century France|date=1993|publisher=Routledge |page=106 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IeeJAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA106&|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref> Lemaître used the character again in a sequel he co-authored titled ''Robert Macaire'', first presented in 1835.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hamilton| first1=Paul|title=The Oxford Handbook of European Romanticism|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=765| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DXswCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA765&|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref> [[File:Robert Macaire.jpg|thumb|Frontispiece: G. W. M. Reynolds' ''Robert Macaire; or the French Bandit in England'' (London: J. Dicks, 1839)]] The British author [[George W. M. Reynolds|George William MacArthur Reynolds]] authored a penny dreadful entitled ''Robert Macaire; or, The French Bandit in England'' (1839).<ref>{{cite book| accessdate = 8 January 2017 | title = British Writers and Paris: 1830-1875 | first= Elizabeth | last = Jay | page= 270 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hZFPCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA270& | date = 2016 | publisher = Oxford University Press}}</ref>
The book ''Physiologie du Robert-Macaire'' (1842) written by [[Pierre-Joseph Rousseau]] (1797–1849) and illustrated by [[Honoré Daumier]]<ref>{{cite web | publisher= Museum of Fine Arts Boston | accessdate = 19 February 2016 | title = Physiologie du Robert-Macaire | url = http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/physiologie-du-robert-macaire-167930 }}</ref> identified Macaire with a variety of contemporary social types, all involved in "shady schemes for instant wealth", and especially [[Émile de Girardin]] (1806-1881), a businessman who promoted his financial adventures through his own newspaper, ''[[La Presse (French newspaper)|La Presse]]''.<ref name=ramus/> Daumier also published a series of a hundred lithographs of Macaire in ''Charivari'' between 1836 and 1842.<ref>{{cite book| pages=41–2 | title= Caricature and French Political Culture 1830-1848: Charles Philipon and the Illustrated Press | first=David S. | last=Kerr | publisher= Oxford University Press| date=2000 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YXNO_Jc1eb0C&pg=PA42& }}</ref>
[[Edward Jakobowski]] based his comic opera ''[[Erminie]]'' on an English translation of the play '' Robert Macaire''. It premiered in London in 1885. It had a considerable success. Its first New York production ran for 571 performances.
Two silent films used the character Macaire: ''[[Robert Macaire and Bertrand]]'' (1906) and ''The Adventures of Robert Macaire'' (1925).
The French film ''[[Children of Paradise|Les Enfants du Paradis]]'' (1945), set in the 1830s, presents [[Pierre Brasseur]] as Lemaître playing the role of Macaire.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Butler|first1=Margaret|title=Film and Community in Britain and France: From La Regle du Jeu to Room at the Top|date=2004|publisher=I.B. Tauris|page=65|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4jMBAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA65 |accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
''La Robert-Macaire'' was the name of a popular dance, mentioned along with the [[cancan]] in an 1841 play.<ref>{{cite book | accessdate = 14 February 2017| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nQNfAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA22& | page = 22 | title = 1841 et 1941, ou aujourd'hui et dans cent ans, revue fantastique en deux actes | language = fr | quote = Messieurs les étudians, / S'en vont à la Chaumière, / Pour y danser l'cancan, / Et la Robert-Macaire ! | author= Cognard Frères and Théodore Muret | date= 1841 | publisher = Lacombe }}</ref>
French cuisine includes a vegetarian potato dish called ''pommes de terre Macaire''.<ref>{{cite news | work = New York Times | first = Pierre | last = Franey | accessdate = 19 February 2016 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1985/12/18/garden/holiday-classics-to-give-the-cook-a-magic-touch.html?pagewanted=3 |title = Holiday Classics to Give the Cook a Magic Touch | date = 18 December 1985 }}</ref>
==Earlier use of the name== Before Lemaître created his politically-charged Macaire character, the name Robert Macaire was associated with a figure in a 14th-century legend who was required to engage in trail-by-combat with a dog. A melodrama called ''[[The Dog of Montarges|Le Chien de Montargis, ou la Forêt de Bondy]]'' premiered in Paris on 18 June 1814 and ran until 1834. It was translated into English<ref>{{cite book|last1=Barrymore |first1= William|title=Murder Will Out, or The Dog of Montargis|year=1814|page=55|edition=Plays Submitted to the Lord Chamberlain| first2=John| last2= Fawcett }}</ref> and German. In an English-language compendium of oddities published in 1869, Macaire murders a man in the forest of [[Bondy]] on the outskirts of Paris. The only witness to survive in the victim's dog. King [[Charles V of France|Charles V]] orders a trial by combat and the dog defeats Macaire, which leads to Macaire's conviction and hanging.<ref>{{cite book | accessdate = 19 February 2016 | title = The Book of Days: A Miscellany of Popular Antiquities | chapter= October 8th | url = http://www.thebookofdays.com/months/oct/8.htm | year = 1869 | first = Robert | last = Chambers}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|0227396|Robert Macaire et Bertrand}} *{{IMDb title|0200457|Les Aventures de Robert Macaire}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Macaire, Robert}} [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1823]] [[Category:Fictional outlaws]] [[Category:Fictional career criminals]] [[Category:Fictional criminals]] [[Category:Theatre characters]]

revision.comment: /* top */link to state party, replaced: [[Australian Labor Party| → [[Australian Labor Party (Tasmanian Branch)|, [[Australian Labor Party]] → [[Australian Labor Party (Tasmanian Branch)|Labor Party]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Roy Fagan |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = |alt = |caption = |order = 2nd |office = Deputy Premier of Tasmania |term_start = 12 May 1959 |term_end = 26 May 1969 |premier = [[Eric Reece]] |predecessor = [[John James Dwyer]] |successor = [[Kevin Lyons]] |office2 = Attorney-General of Tasmania |term_start2 = 10 December 1946 |term_end2 = 19 July 1958 |premier2 = [[Robert Cosgrove]] |predecessor2 = [[Eric Ogilvie]] |successor2 = [[Bill Neilson]] |term_start3 = 12 May 1959 |term_end3 = 26 May 1969 |premier3 = [[Eric Reece]] |predecessor3 = [[Eric Reece]] |successor3 = [[Max Bingham]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1905|12|28|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Waratah, Tasmania]], Australia |death_date = {{Death date and age|1990|7|18|1905|12|28|df=y}} |death_place = [[Hobart]], [[Tasmania]], Australia |birthname = Roy Frederick Fagan |nationality = Australian |party = [[Australian Labor Party (Tasmanian Branch)|Labor Party]] |spouse = Gertrude Estelle Cooney (1925–1946; her death)
Mavis Isabel Smith (1947–1990; his death) |relations = |children = Three sons, one daughter |residence = |alma_mater = [[University of Tasmania]] |occupation = |profession = [[Barrister]] and [[solicitor]] |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = }} '''Roy Frederick Fagan''' (28 December 1905 – 18 July 1990) was an Australian [[Australian Labor Party (Tasmanian Branch)|Labor Party]] politician, who was [[Deputy Premier of Tasmania]] from 1959 to 1969. ==Early life== Fagan was born in [[Waratah, Tasmania]] in 1905, the eldest son of James Fagan and Annie Theresa Breheney. His younger siblings were two brothers, Kevin and Vin, and a sister, Sheila.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69967603 |title=Obituary paragraphs. |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Tasmania)|The Advocate]] |location=Burnie, Tas. |date=12 April 1954 |accessdate=21 March 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} His Catholic mother sent him to [[St Virgil's College]] in Hobart to be schooled, although his Catholicism lapsed once he moved out of home and he was later known to be an [[Agnosticism|agnostic]] who did not attend Mass.[[Michael Field (Australian politician)|Michael Field]], [http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/fagan-roy-frederick-12473/text22435 'Fagan, Roy Frederick (1905–1990)'], ''Australian Dictionary of Biography'', National Centre of Biography, Australian National University, accessed 18 March 2013. On leaving school, Fagan joined the staff of the [[Commonwealth Bank of Australia|Commonwealth Bank]] where he worked until 1929, when he resigned to attend university.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article24954972 |title=ADMITTED TO BAR. |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart, Tas. |date=9 August 1934 |accessdate=21 March 2013 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} ==Education and legal career== In 1930, Fagan commenced studies for a law degree at the [[University of Tasmania]]. In 1931, he was [[Articled clerk|articled]] to the firm Gatenby, Johnson & Walker, and in May 1934 he graduated and was admitted to the [[Bachelor of Laws]] (LLB). During his studies, he had taken a keen interest in all aspects of university life, and was heavily involved with the [[Tasmania University Union]], serving as the body's president for three years. He was [[Admission to practice law|admitted to the Bar]] in August 1934, after what the Hobart ''Mercury'' newspaper called a "brilliant university career". Fagan also completed a Bachelor of Arts and graduated in May 1935.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91723944 |title=DEGREES CONFERRED AT UNIVERSITY. |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Tasmania)|The Advocate]] |location=Burnie, Tas. |date=15 May 1935 |accessdate=21 March 2013 |page=7 Edition: DAILY |publisher=National Library of Australia}} ==Political career== Fagan was asked by the Premier of Tasmania, [[Robert Cosgrove]], to stand for the seat of [[Division of Lyons (state)|Wilmot]] at the [[Tasmanian state election, 1946]]. Immediately following declaration of his election, Fagan was appointed Attorney-General in Cosgrove's cabinet.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article26416884 |title=A Minister Shunned Publicity |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart, Tas. |date=7 June 1947 |accessdate=18 March 2013 |page=2 Supplement: The Mercury Magazine |publisher=National Library of Australia}} ==Personal life== On 8 December 1925, aged 19, Fagan married Estelle Cooney, a shop assistant, in [[Wynyard, Tasmania|Wynyard]]. Cooney was pregnant at the time of their marriage, but did not live with Fagan between the time of the daughter's birth or afterwards. Fagan, although he remained married to Estelle, from the early 1930s was in a domestic relationship with fellow university student Mavis Smith. When Estelle died in 1946, Fagan married Smith at a Catholic church in [[Bellerive, Tasmania|Bellerive]] on 28 January 1947. They would have three sons. ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Eric Ogilvie]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Attorney-General of Tasmania]]|years=1946–1958}} {{s-aft|after=[[Bill Neilson]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Eric Reece]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Attorney-General of Tasmania]]|years=1959–1969}} {{s-aft|after=[[Max Bingham]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[John James Dwyer]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Deputy Premier of Tasmania]]|years=1959–1969}} {{s-aft|after=[[John James Dwyer]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fagan, Roy}} [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:Members of the Tasmanian House of Assembly]] [[Category:Deputy Premiers of Tasmania]] [[Category:Australian barristers]] [[Category:Australian solicitors]] [[Category:University of Tasmania alumni]] [[Category:University of Tasmania faculty]] [[Category:People with Alzheimer's disease]] [[Category:Australian Labor Party members of the Parliament of Tasmania]] [[Category:20th-century Australian politicians]]

{{Infobox person | name = Satyanarayana Rajguru | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1903|08|19}} | birth_place = [[Odisha]], India | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|1997|06|11|1903|08|19}} | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | othername = | occupation = Epigraphist, writer, historian | yearsactive = | known for = Studies in Odisha history | spouse = Taramani Devi | domesticpartner = | children = 4 son and 1 daughter | parents = Harikrushna Rajguru
Sunamani Devi | website = | awards = [[Padma Shri]]
[[Sahitya Akademi Award]]
[[Odisha Sahitya Academy Award]] }} '''Satyanarayana Rajguru''' was an Indian litterateur, epigraphist and historian.{{cite web | url=http://gajapati.nic.in/sonsofsoil/eminent%5Cemiperson.htm | title=Padmashree Satyanarayana Rajguru | publisher=Gajapati | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://odisha.gov.in/e-magazine/Orissareview/2010/April/engpdf/58-64.pdf | title=Memories of My Father | publisher=Government of Odisha | date=2010 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} He was a curator and epigraphist at the [[Odisha State Museum]] and was a recipient of [[Sahitya Akademi Award]], ''Bharati Bhushan'' award, Ganjam Sahitya Sammilani award, [[Odisha Sahitya Academy Award]] and ''Sarala Sanman''. The [[Government of India]] awarded him the fourth highest Indian civilian award of [[Padma Shri]] in 1974.{{cite web | url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf | title=Padma Shri | publisher=Padma Shri | date=2015 | accessdate=November 11, 2014}} ==Biography== Born on 19 August 1903 to Harikrushna Rajguru and Sunamani Devi in the Indian state of [[Odisha]], Rajguru passed the ''Oriya and Sanskrit'' title examination from [[Andhra University]] and started his career in 1929 as the manager of ''Parala Padmanabha Rangalaya'', the first theatre in Odisha, founded by Padmanabha Narayan Deb, erstwhile Raja of the state of Parala.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sHklK65TKQ0C&pg=PA565&lpg=PA565&dq=Parala+Padmanabha+Rangalaya&source=bl&ots=sRBS3gZrU9&sig=rZbw7L_kPc6tzI_Wk6ZUrfchr5w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI8JX035ONxgIVROwUCh1hawCm#v=onepage&q=Parala%20Padmanabha%20Rangalaya&f=false | title=History of Indian Literature, Volume 1 | publisher=Sahitya Akademi | author=Sisir Kumar Das | year=2000 | pages=815 | isbn=9788172010065}} During his tenure there, he was associated with the activities of [[Utkal Sammilani]] and assisted [[Krushna Chandra Gajapati]] in the formation of Odisha state in 1937; he is known to have submitted a thesis on the state reorganization. Rajguru, after his tenure as the president of the [[Ganjam District]] Education Council (1942–45), worked as an assistant at the Kalinga Historical Research Society at [[Bhawanipatna]] from 1947 and later, joined [[Odisha State Museum]] to work as a curator (1950–61) and later as an epigraphist (1963–70). He was a member of the working committee of Odisha Sahitya Academy and the chairman of [[Paralakhemundi]] Municipality. He was a life member of [[Berhampur University]] and was awarded DLitt by the university. Rajguru is known to have done notable research on the history of Odisha{{cite web | url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924063477313/cu31924063477313_djvu.txt | title=Inscriptions of Orissa | publisher=Cornell University Library | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} and is credited with findings on the early of life of [[Jayadeva]], the thirteenth century [[Sanskrit literature|Sanskrit]] poet and the author of [[Gita Govinda]].{{cite web | url=http://www.poemhunter.com/i/ebooks/pdf/jayadeva_2012_9.pdf | title=Jayadeva (1200 AD) | publisher=Poem Hunter | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} He translated ''The Palanquin Bearers'', a poem by [[Sarojini Naidu]] into [[Odia language]] under the name, ''Palinki Bahaka'' and has published several other works, some of which are prescribed text for university studies.{{cite web | url=http://ddceutkal.org/Journal/Search_Journal_2013_Vol-I.pdf | title=Historical Background of Gopinath & Radha Krishna | publisher=Utkal University | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * Mo Jeevana Sangrama (autobiography){{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Mo-Jibana-Sangram-Rajagurudr-Satyanarayan/dp/B0018Y3VN0 | title=Mo Jibana Sangram | publisher=Sri Balabhadra Rath | author=Satyanarayana Rajguru | year=1994 | ASIN=B0018Y3VN0}} * Swapane Chumban * Janani Utkal * Radhavisek * Odia Lipira Krama Bikash{{cite web | url=http://www.davcollegekoraput.org.in/LibraryBooks.asp?pgno=186 | title=Odia Lipira Krama Bikash | publisher=DAV College | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150615164141/http://www.davcollegekoraput.org.in/LibraryBooks.asp?pgno=186 | archivedate=June 15, 2015 | df= }} * History of Gangas{{cite web | url=http://odisha.gov.in/e-magazine/journal/journalvol3/pdf/15-27.pdf | title=History of theGangas | publisher=Government of Odisha | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} * The Korasanda Copper Plate Grant of Visakhavarmma * History of Eastern Gangas of Kalinga{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7LFzfbhmJcMC&pg=PA20&lpg=PA20&dq=History+of+Ganges+rajguru&source=bl&ots=ULZy17KX3E&sig=k3egI838KSzAk2mVEKGaoSsF8ls&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDIQ6AEwA2oVChMI0d-nzKGNxgIVy-0UCh1tPwD8#v=onepage&q=History%20of%20Ganges%20rajguru&f=false | title=The History of Medieval Vaishnavism in Orissa | publisher=Asian Educational Services | date=1981 | accessdate=June 13, 2015 | author=Prabhat Mukherjee | pages=200}} * Heirographic Letters of Naraj * The Odras and their Predominency * The Historical Research in Orissa * The Konduli Copper Plate Grant of Narasimha Deva of Saka 1305 * Sumandal Plates of Dharmaraj * Ranpur plates of Dharmaraja{{cite web | url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/34826/15/15_appendice.pdf | title=Ranpur plates of Dharmaraja | publisher=Shodhganga | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} * Historical Background of Gopinath & Radha Krishna * Oriya Inscription on a Stone Image{{cite web | url=http://www.southasiaarchive.com/Content/sarf.120364 | title=Oriya Inscription on a Stone Image | publisher=South Asia Archive | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} * South Indian Inscriptions{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1AA9W9_4Z9gC&pg=PA112&lpg=PA112&dq=The+Historical+Research+in+Orissa+Rajguru&source=bl&ots=Eye-OnyOID&sig=F3fSfmZKnd12vFJVzmtBWuGnvho&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAGoVChMIyLiklaONxgIVTDwUCh10fQDv#v=onepage&q=The%20Historical%20Research%20in%20Orissa%20Rajguru&f=false | title=Economic History of Orissa | publisher=Indus Publishing | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015 | author=Nihar Ranjan Patnaik}} {{div col end}} Satyanarayana Rajguru died on 11 June 1997 at the age of 93, his wife Taramani Devi preceding him in death by one year. He is survived by his sons Gopeshwar rajguru, Radha Raman rajguru and sitakant rajguru. ==Honours, awards and recognition== Rajguru was awarded the civilian honour [[Padma Shri]] in 1974 by the [[Government of India]]. He received the [[Sahitya Akademi Award]] for his autobiography, ''Mo Jeevana Sangrama'' in 1996.{{cite web | url=http://sahitya-akademi.gov.in/sahitya-akademi/awards/akademi%20samman_suchi.jsp#ODIA | title=Akademi Awards (1955-2014) | publisher=Sahitya Akademi | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} He was also a recipient of ''Bharati Bhushan'' award from [[Andhra Mahasabha]], Ganjam Sahitya Sammilani award (1968) and Odisha Sahitya Academy award (1968). A recipient of ''Sarala Sanman'' (1989) from Sarala Sansad,{{cite web | url=http://incredibleorissa.com/en/sarala-samman-2011-ramakant-rath/ | title=Sarala Samman 2011 to Ramakant Rath | publisher=Incredible Orissa | date=2015 | accessdate=June 13, 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Mo-Jibana-Sangram-Rajagurudr-Satyanarayan/dp/B0018Y3VN0 | title=Mo Jibana Sangram | publisher=Sri Balabhadra Rath | author=Satyanarayana Rajguru | year=1994 | ASIN=B0018Y3VN0}} * {{cite web | url=http://satyanarayanrajguru.blogspot.ae/2013_08_01_archive.html | title=Padmashree Satyanarayan Rajguru | publisher=Google Blogger | work=Blog | date=29 August 2013 | accessdate=June 13, 2015 | author=Satyanarayana Rajguru}} {{Padma Award winners of Odisha}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rajguru, Satyanarayana}} [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Shri in literature & education]] [[Category:Recipients of the Sahitya Akademi Award in Odia]] [[Category:Poets from Odisha]] [[Category:20th-century Indian translators]] [[Category:Indian epigraphers]] [[Category:Museum people]] [[Category:20th-century Indian poets]] [[Category:20th-century Indian linguists]] [[Category:Andhra University alumni]] [[Category:Indian male poets]] [[Category:Scientists from Odisha]] [[Category:20th-century Indian male writers]]

[[File:Seth MacFarlane (7601675800).jpg|350px|right|thumb|MacFarlane at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International]], July 2012]] [[Seth MacFarlane]] is an American actor, animator, writer, producer, director, comedian, and singer.{{cite web |url=https://tv.yahoo.com/seth-macfarlane/contributor/663655/bio;_ylt=Aon954w635FJbS9IA6nuh_2.o9EF |title=Seth MacFarlane – Biography |publisher=Yahoo! |accessdate=December 20, 2007}} MacFarlane began his career as an animator and writer for [[Hanna-Barbera]] for several television series, including ''[[Johnny Bravo]]'', ''[[Cow and Chicken]]'', ''[[Dexter's Laboratory]]'', ''[[I Am Weasel]]'', and created a sequel to his college thesis film ''[[The Life of Larry and Larry & Steve|Larry & Steve]]''. Since 1999, MacFarlane has served has creator, writer, executive producer, and lead voice actor in the adult animated sitcom ''[[Family Guy]]'' on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]. He voices the characters of [[Peter Griffin]], [[Stewie Griffin]], [[Brian Griffin]] and among other characters. The series has garnered critical acclaim with critics and audiences and has won numerous awards. Since then MacFarlane has co-created, co-writes, executive produces, and lead voices in FOX's ''[[American Dad!]]'' and wrote, co-created, executive produced, and had a supporting voice role in ''[[The Cleveland Show]]'', which was a spin-off of ''Family Guy''. In 2012, MacFarlane made his feature film directorial debut with ''[[Ted (film)|Ted]]'', a fantasy comedy which was well received by critics and audiences. He went on to act, write, produce, and direct two features for [[Universal Studios]]—the western comedy ''[[A Million Ways to Die in the West]]'' (2014) and a sequel to his first film ''[[Ted 2]]'' (2015). In 2017, MacFarlane created his fourth show, ''[[The Orville]]''. He has also appeared in the films ''[[Hellboy II: The Golden Army]]'' (2008), ''[[Futurama: Into the Wild Green Yonder]]'' (2009), ''[[The Drawn Together Movie: The Movie!]]'' (2010), ''[[Tooth Fairy (2010 film)|Tooth Fairy]]'' (2010), ''[[Movie 43]]'' (2013), ''[[Sing (2016 American film)|Sing]]'' (2016), and ''[[Logan Lucky]]'' (2017). MacFarlane has received [[List of awards and nominations received by Seth MacFarlane|numerous awards and nominations]] for his work on film, television, music, and video games. He has also received twenty [[Emmy Award]] nominations, winning four for ''[[Family Guy]]''. His directorial film debut in ''Ted'' earned him an [[85th Academy Awards|Academy Award nomination]] for [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]]. In addition, he has received four [[Grammy Award]] nominations and two [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] among others. {| class="wikitable" |+Key | style="background:#FFFFCC;"| {{dagger|alt=Works that have not yet been released}} |Denotes works that have not yet been released |} ==Film== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col"| Film ! scope="col"| Role ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | {{abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1995 ! scope="row"| ''[[The Life of Larry and Larry & Steve#The Life of Larry .281995.29|The Life of Larry]]'' | Larry, Steve, Lois (voice) / Himself | Student film | style="text-align:center;"|{{cite book|last=Lenburg|first=Jeff|title=Who's who in animated cartoons: an international guide to film & television's award-winning and legendary animators|publisher=Applause Theatre & Cinema Books|location=New York|year=2006|edition=Illustrated|page=221|isbn=978-1-55783-671-7}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2005 ! scope="row"| ''Inside the CIA'' | [[Stan Smith (American Dad!)|Stan Smith]], [[Roger (American Dad!)|Roger]] (voice) | Short film | style="text-align:center;"| http://www.amc.com/movie/2005/Inside+the+CIA/ |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2005 ! scope="row"| ''[[Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story]]'' | [[Stewie Griffin]], [[Peter Griffin]], [[Brian Griffin]], Various voices |Direct-to-video

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Sherman Houston Dudley | image = Sherman_Dudley.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1870-3 | birth_place = | death_date = March 1, 1940 | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = Lone Star Comedian | known_for = | occupation = [[Vaudeville]] }} '''Sherman Houston Dudley''' (1872 – March 1, 1940) was an African-American [[vaudeville]] performer and theatre entrepreneur. He gained notability in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century as an individual performer, a composer of [[ragtime]] songs, and as a member and later owner of various minstrel shows including the [[Smart Set (minstrel show)|Smart Set]]. Dudley is also notable as one of the first African Americans to combine business with theater, by starting a black theater circuit, in which theaters were owned or operated by African Americans and provided entertainment by and for African Americans.
==Career== Reportedly, Dudley was born in 1872 in [[Dallas]], Texas (some sources list his year of birth as 1870<ref name=monsho/> or 1873<ref name=southern/>), "of humble parentage".<ref name=abbot87>Abbot and Seroff 87.</ref> A jockey early in his youth, he turned to theater and gained a reputation by singing in a [[medicine show]] on a Dallas street corner, singing "[[Dese Bones G'wine Rise Again]]". By 1897 he had his own show, the "S. H. Dudley's Georgia Minstrels", who were performing in [[Galveston]]; later that same year he was on tour with [[P. T. Wright]]'s Nashville Students Company. He gained a reputation for writing popular [[coon song]]s (including a hit song called "Mr. Coon, You'se Too Black For Me"),<ref name=abbot87/> and performed with a number of minstrel comedians in shows in the same vein, including ''A Holiday in Coonville'' (his own production) and ''Coontown Golf Club'' (a production by Tom Brown<ref>Hill and Hatch 141-42.</ref> and Sam Cousins<ref>Brooks 602.</ref>).<ref>Abbot and Seroff 88-89.</ref> When he toured with Tom Brown and [[Billy Kersands]] in 1902, it was clear that he was a popular, well-known artist in the South, and was billed as "the Lone-Star comedian". In 1903 he married Alberta Ormes, with whom he'd been performing since at least 1901, and was on tour the following year with [[Richard and Pringle's Georgia Minstrels]].<ref name=abbot89/> By this time, he received star billing.<ref name=brooks520/> In the summer of 1904, however, he left that company and moved to Chicago to take over the leading role in [[Gus Hill]]'s Smart Set<ref name=brooks520>Brooks 520.</ref> after the death of [[Tom McIntosh (comedian)|Tom McIntosh]], performing in the show ''A Southern Enchantment''.<ref name=abbot89>Abbot and Seroff 89.</ref>
Dudley performed with the Smart Set for years with great success, though one critic, Sylvester Russell (a writer for the ''[[Indianapolis Freeman]]''), was hard on him from the beginning, presumably because he felt that Dudley's minstrel show background made him unworthy; in 1906, Russell referred to him as "this loathsome comedian who hails from the Lone Star State." It seems that Dudley took all this in stride until 1911, when Russell made a comment about Dudley's son, after which Dudley beat him up "$5,000 worth", according to Russell; Dudley was arrested and fined $1 and court costs, after which Russell sued him for $5,000. Other critics were less hesitant to praise Dudley's performance, and he is now credited with having brought "the street to the stage": "Dudley revitalized the Smart Set and made it into an enduring classic of the American popular stage."<ref>Abbot and Seroff 90.</ref> In the next Smart Set show, ''The Black Politician'' (1906), Dudley got to use his jockey skills riding a horse on stage, and when in October 1906 a donkey named Shamus O'Brien was added (though another source lists the donkey's name as "Patrick"<ref name=brooks520/>), the donkey and Dudley received high praise from critics, even from Russell.<ref>Abbot and Seroff 96-98.</ref>
In 1909, the Smart Set split up in a Northern and a Southern Smart Set, the first being directed by Dudley and the latter by his understudy, [[Tutt Brothers|Salem Tutt Whitney]]; their 1909-10 production, ''His Honor, the Barber'' was written by a white playwright, [[Edwin Handford]], with music written for the show by black composers [[James Tim Brymn]], [[Chris Smith (composer)|Chris Smith]], and [[James Burris]]. The show opened in New Jersey for a mixed audience, and by the time of the final run [[Aida Overton Walker]] had joined the cast.<ref>Abbot and Seroff 102-104.</ref> By this time, Dudley was widely known as the "Lone Star Comedian" and had begun to expand his business ventures, moving into theater in an attempt to have a black-owned and operated string of venues around the United States, a dream of his since at least 1907.<ref name=abbot106>Abbot and Seroff 106-107.</ref>
By about 1910 Dudley was based in Washington D.C., where he served as general manager and treasurer of the [[Colored Actors' Union]]. In 1911 he set up S. H. Dudley Theatrical Enterprises, and began buying and leasing theaters to develop the first black vaudeville circuit, initially around Washington and Virginia;<ref name=monsho>{{cite web|last=Monsho|first=Kharen|title=Dudley, Sherman H.|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fdumj|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=5 April 2012}}</ref> he had bought his first theater, in Baltimore, in 1912.<ref name=southern>Southern 297-98.</ref> In August 1912, he played his last season with the Smart Set, from then on devoting himself to his "circuit of theaters."<ref name=abbot106/> By 1916 the "Dudley Circuit" had extended into the south and Midwest, enabling black entertainers to secure longer term contracts for an extended season; his circuit provided the basis for the [[Theater Owners Bookers Association]] (TOBA).<ref name=monsho/> His circuit was advertised in a weekly column published in black newspapers, "What's What on the Dudley's Circuit", and by 1914 it included over twenty theaters, "all owned or operated by blacks and as far south as Atlanta." TOBA was founded by people associated with Dudley's circuit, and while the organization was white-owned it had black regional managers, including Dudley (for the Washington, D.C. area).<ref name=southern/>
After 1917 Dudley devoted himself to producing black musicals, including updated Smart Set productions. He sold his theaters around 1930 (due to economic forces "beyond his control"<ref name=southern/>), and retired to a farm in Maryland where he bred thoroughbred racehorses.<ref name=monsho/>
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}} ;Works cited *{{cite book|last=Abbott|first=Lynn|title=Ragged but right: black traveling shows, "coon songs," and the dark pathway to blues and jazz|year=2007|publisher=UP of Mississippi|location=Jackson|isbn=9781578069019|url=http://www.books.google.com/books?id=u4rc-BKNCyoC&dq|edition=1|author2=Seroff, Doug}} *{{cite book|last=Brooks|first=Tim|title=Lost sounds: blacks and the birth of the recording industry, 1890-1919|year=2005|publisher=U of Illinois P|location=Urbana|isbn=9780252028502|url=http://www.books.google.com/books?id=r-k9ysIaaEUC&pg=PA602}} *{{cite book|last=Hill|first=Errol G.|title=A history of African American theatre|year=2004|publisher=Cambridge UP|location=Cambridge|isbn=9780521624435|pages=141–42|url=http://www.books.google.com/books?id=4ePerohXDIUC&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141|edition=Reprint.|author2=Hatch, James V.}} *{{cite book|last=Southern|first=Eileen|title=The music of black Americans: a history|year=1997|publisher=Norton|location=New York|isbn=9780393038439|pages=297–98|url=http://www.books.google.com/books?id=PSvxJtF3_fUC&pg=PA297|edition=3}}

| 1996 Atlanta | 100 m}} {{Medal|Silver | 1996 Atlanta | 200 m}} {{Medal|Silver | 1996 Atlanta | 400 m}} {{Medal|Bronze | [[1988 Summer Paralympics|1988 Seoul]] | 400 m}} {{Medal|Competition|[[IPC Championships|2006 Assen]] |200m}} {{Medal|Silver| [[1998 Disability World Athletics Championships|1998 Birmingham]] |400m}} {{Medal|Silver| [[1998 Disability World Athletics Championships|1998 Birmingham]] |800m}} {{Medal|Silver| [[2006 IPC Athletics World Championships|2006 Assen]] | 800m}} {{Medal|Bronze| [[2006 IPC Athletics World Championships|2006 Assen]] |400m}} }} }} '''Carys Davina Grey-Thompson, Baroness Grey-Thompson''',{{London Gazette|issue=59333|page=2425|date=12 February 2010}} [[Order of the British Empire|DBE]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] (born 26 July 1969), known as '''Tanni Grey-Thompson''', is a British [[politician]], [[television presenter]] and former [[wheelchair racer]]. She has also been the Chancellor of [[Northumbria University]] since July 2015.{{cite web |url=https://northumbria.ac.uk/about-us/leadership-governance/chancellor/|title=Chancellor |accessdate=8 July 2017}} Grey-Thompson was born with [[spina bifida]] and is a wheelchair user. She is one of the most successful disabled athletes in the UK. She graduated from [[Loughborough University]] in 1991 with a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] (Hons) degree in [[Political science|Politics and Social Administration]]. ==Athletic career== Grey-Thompson's Paralympic career started in the 100m at the Junior National Games for Wales in 1984. Her international career began in 1988 in [[Seoul]], where she won a bronze medal in the 400m. As a young athlete she also competed in [[wheelchair basketball]]. Her fifth and last Paralympic Games were in Athens (2004) where she won two gold medals in [[wheelchair racing]] in the 100m and 400m.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/insideout/northeast/series6/tanni_grey.shtml|title=BBC Inside Out - Tanni Grey Thompson - Handing on the baton|website=www.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=28 September 2017}} In total in her Paralympic career she won 16 medals (11 gold, four silver and a bronze) and also 13 World Championship medals (six gold, five silver and two bronze). On 27 February 2007 Grey-Thompson announced her pending retirement, with her last appearance for Great Britain at May's Paralympic World Cup in [[Manchester]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/disability_sport/6400407.stm Grey Thompson confirms retirement], BBC Sport, 28 February 2007 Over her career she won a total of 16 [[Paralympics|Paralympic]] medals, including 11 golds, held over 30 [[world record]]s and won the [[London Marathon]] six times between 1992 and 2002. ==Post-retirement== In preparation for her retirement from the track, she expanded her television presenting career on [[BBC Wales]] and [[S4C]], as well as [[BBC One]]. During her competitive career she sat on the board of the National Disability Council, The Sports Council for Wales, the English Lottery Awards Panel and UK Sport., and also sat for three years on the Mission 2012 panel (part of UK Sport). Grey-Thompson currently sits on the board of the [[London Marathon]] (2007), the board of [[Transport for London]]{{cite web |url=https://tfl.gov.uk/corporate/about-tfl/how-we-work/corporate-governance/board-members |publisher=Transport for London |title=Board Members |accessdate=20 December 2016 }} (since 2008) and the [[London Legacy Development Corporation]]. She is Chair of the Women's Sports and Fitness Foundation Commission on the Future of Women's Sport. She chairs the board of [[ukactive]]. Grey-Thompson is patron of numerous charities including Sportsleaders UK, a trustee of V, the Duke of Edinburgh Awards scheme, Sportsaid Foundation and the Wembley Stadium Legacy Trust. She is an Academy member of the Laureus World Sport Academy and a trustee of the Sport for Good Foundation. She is also a Council member for the Winston Churchill Memorial Trust and an International Inspiration Ambassador. As well as this she is the Patron of the Tees Wheelyboats Club, a group providing disabled people with access to the [[River Tees]],{{cite web|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/2011/09/26/baroness-tanni-grey-thompson-launches-new-river-tees-wheelyboat-84229-29481675/#ixzz1jXti3W1M| title=Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson launches new River Tees Wheelyboat|author=Hole, Chris|work=Evening Gazette|date=26 September 2011|accessdate=15 January 2012}} and a board member of the [[Tony Blair Sports Foundation]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20111127224259/http://www.tonyblairsportsfoundation.org/sports/pages/sports-board-members/ Tony Blaire Sports Foundation Board Members] In July 2011 Grey-Thompson was announced as the President of the Leadership 20:20 Commission, the Commission on the future leadership of Civil Society. She launched the Commission's recommendations in Parliament on 14 December 2011. Grey-Thompson has also been the [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of [[Northumbria University]] since July 2015. ===Parliamentary career=== On 23 March 2010, Grey-Thompson was created a [[Life Peer]] on the recommendation of the [[House of Lords Appointments Commission]] (HOLAC). Despite previously suggesting a desire for a title with a Welsh connection,{{cite news|title= Baroness Tanni determined her title will have a Welsh connection|author=Tomos Livingstone |newspaper=Western Mail |date=6 February 2010|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/baroness-tanni-determined-title-welsh-1933527|accessdate=30 January 2018}} her title was conferred as Baroness Grey-Thompson, of [[Eaglescliffe]] in the [[County of Durham]] on 23 March 2010.{{London Gazette|issue=59375|page=5330|date=26 March 2010}} Grey-Thompson was introduced in the [[House of Lords]] on 29 March,{{cite web|author=Department of the Official Report (Hansard), House of Lords, Westminster |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200910/ldhansrd/text/100329-0001.htm#1003292000403 |title=House of Lords – Hansard |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |date=29 March 2010 |accessdate=10 March 2017}} swearing the [[oath of allegiance]] in both [[English language|English]] and [[Welsh language|Welsh]] and sits as a [[crossbencher]].[http://www.dodonline.co.uk/engine.asp?lev1=4&lev2=38&menu=98&biog=y&group=5&tab=4&id=84715 Profile] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606001859/http://www.dodonline.co.uk/engine.asp?lev1=4&lev2=38&menu=98&biog=y&group=5&tab=4&id=84715 |date=6 June 2013 }}, dodonline.co.uk; accessed 7 April 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.parliament.uk/biographies/lords/baroness-grey-thompson/3862|title=Baroness Grey-Thompson|website=UK Parliament|accessdate=14 October 2017}} In Aug 2014, Grey-Thompson was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' opposing [[Scottish independence]] in the run-up to September's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|referendum on that issue]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/07/celebrities-open-letter-scotland-independence-full-text|title=Celebrities' open letter to Scotland – full text and list of signatories|publisher=theguardian.com|accessdate=26 August 2014}} ==Honours== In 1993 she was appointed [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE){{London Gazette|issue=53153|date=31 December 1992|page=14 |supp=y}} for "services to sport", advanced in 2000 to Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE){{London Gazette |issue=55710 |date=31 December 1999 |page=17 |supp=y}} again for "services to sport" and then in 2005 was promoted to [[Dame Commander]] of the Order of the British Empire (DBE).{{London Gazette|issue=57509|date=31 December 2004|page=7 |supp=y}} She has received numerous honorary degrees including Honorary Doctorates from Oxford University, the University of Greenwich, Bath University, Newcastle University, Oxford Brookes University, Liverpool John Moores, the University of Leicester, Sheffield Hallam University, University of Hull, University of Exeter, Heriot Watt University, the Open University, University of Wales Newport, the University of Wales, Leeds Metropolitan University, Loughborough University (both a Master and Doctorate), Teesside University, York and Ripon College, University of Swansea, University of Glamorgan, UWIC, University of Surrey, Southampton University, Manchester Metropolitan University, Staffordshire University and Cardiff University. Grey-Thompson received a Lifetime Achievement Award and another Honorary Doctorate from the [[University of East London]] in May 2011, at the university's annual Sports Award evening held at [[West Ham United]]'s [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] stadium.{{Cite web|url=https://www.speakersassociates.com/speaker/tanni-grey-thompson|title=www.speakersassociates.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s7UpRv93yyQ|title=www.youtube.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} Grey-Thompson was named the [[BBC Wales Sports Personality of the Year]] three times; in 1992, 2000 and 2004. In 2000, she came third in the [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year]], behind [[Steve Redgrave]] and [[Denise Lewis]]. That year she also received the [[Helen Rollason Award]] for her performance at the [[2000 Summer Paralympics]]. In August 2009, she was made a member of the [[Gorsedd]] at the 2009 [[National Eisteddfod]] in [[Bala, Gwynedd|Bala]], [[Gwynedd]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/8113614.stm|title=Gorsedd honour for female stars|publisher=BBC Wales|date=23 June 2009|accessdate=7 April 2016}} [[Willenhall School Sports College]], [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]] has named a [[House system|house]] in her honour, where each of the eight houses is named after influential sports stars and local heroes. [[Roundwood Park School]] set up a house system in 2011. In July 2012, the blue house became Grey-Thompson house.{{Cite web|url=https://roundwoodpark.co.uk/houses/|title=roundwoodpark.co.uk|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} In November 2012 she was appointed to the three-person commission that has been set up by the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] to investigate the [[Lance Armstrong]] doping affair.{{cite web|last=Slater |first=Matt |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cycling/20555534 |title=BBC Sport - Lance Armstrong affair: Tanni Grey-Thompson on investigation panel|publisher=Bbc.co.uk|date=30 November 2012|accessdate=26 August 2014}} In February 2013 she was assessed as one of the 100 most powerful women in the United Kingdom by ''[[Woman's Hour]]'' on [[BBC Radio 4]].[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007qlvb/features/power-list-100 BBC Radio 4, Woman's Hour Power list], bbc.co.uk; accessed 7 April 2016. In July 2013, she received another honorary Doctor of Science (HonDSc) in recognition of her outstanding service to disability and to disadvantaged people, and to her promotion of sport and the Paralympics.{{cite web |url=http://kentonline.co.uk/medway_messenger/news/11-golds-four-silvers-one-4107|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130824022950/http://kentonline.co.uk/medway_messenger/news/11-golds-four-silvers-one-4107/|dead-url=yes|archivedate=24 August 2013|title=Paralympic athlete Tanni Grey-Thompson receives honorary degree at Rochester Cathedral|publisher=kentonline.co.uk|date=31 July 2013|accessdate=3 August 2013}} On 15 June 2016 she was awarded the degree of Doctor of Law (honoris causa) by the University of Cambridge.{{cite web|url=http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/reporter/2015-16/weekly/6431/section9.shtml#heading2-48 |title=Acta - Cambridge University Reporter 6431 |publisher=Admin.cam.ac.uk |date=22 June 2016 |accessdate=10 March 2017}} ==Her personal life== Grey-Thompson attended [[St Cyres Comprehensive School]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/aug/26/tanni-grey-thompson-paralympic-star|title=www.theguardian.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=31 January 2018}} She is married to Ian Thompson,{{cite web|url=http://www.tanni.co.uk/biography/ |title=Tanni Grey-Thompson |publisher=Tanni.co.uk |date= |accessdate=10 March 2017}} a research chemist and former wheelchair athlete. They live at [[Eaglescliffe]], [[County Durham]]; they have one daughter.https://www.ft.com/content/df3d9764-5f79-11e4-a882-00144feabdc0 She was christened Carys Davina Grey, but her sister referred to her as "tiny" when she first saw her, pronouncing it "tanni"; the nickname stuck.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/wales/8593755.stm|title=Paralympian Tanni Grey-Thompson becomes people's peer|publisher=BBC News|date=29 March 2010}} Her autobiography ''Seize the Day'' was published by [[Hodder and Stoughton]] in 2001. She is a patron of [[Zoё's Place Baby Hospice]], a charity for sick babies and young children.{{Cite web|url=http://www.zoes-place.org.uk/middlesbrough/about/patrons_ambassadors.aspx|title=Patrons & Ambassadors - Welcome to Zoё's Place Baby Hospice|website=www.zoes-place.org.uk|accessdate=27 September 2017}} Grey-Thompson is also patron of the [http://disabilityalliance.org.gg/ Guernsey Disability Alliance.] ==Paralympic World Cup medals== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Event !Position |- |2005 || 100 m || style="background:gold; text-align:center;"| 1st |- |2005 || 400 m || style="background:gold; text-align:center;"| 1st |- |2007 || 200 m || style="background:silver; text-align:center;"| 2nd |} ==Styles and honours== *Ms Tanni Grey, MBE (1993-1999) *Mrs Tanni Grey-Thompson, MBE (1999-2000) *Mrs Tanni Grey-Thompson, OBE (2000-2005) *Dame Tanni Grey-Thompson, DBE (2005-2010) *The Baroness Grey-Thompson, DBE (2010–2012) *The Baroness Grey-Thompson DBE, DL (2012–present) ==References== Note - #{{note|medals}}British Disabled Flying Association (2005). [https://web.archive.org/web/20050204023128/http://www.bdfa.net/tanni2.html Dame Tanni Grey-Thompson OBE, MBE – new patron for the BDFA]. {{hatnote|This is the article about the fourteen infallibles which should not be mistaken for the [[The Twelve Imams]].}} {{The Fourteen Infallible}} '''The Fourteen Infallibles''' ({{lang-ar|معصومون}} '' Ma‘sūmūn'') ({{lang-fa|چهارده معصوم}} '' Chahar'dah Ma‘sūm'') in [[Twelver|Twelver Shia Islam]] are the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]], his daughter [[Fatima Zahra]], and [[Twelve Imams|the Twelve Imams]]. All are considered to be [[ismah|infallible]] under the theological concept of [[Ismah]].{{Harvnb|Dabashi|2006|p=463}}{{harvnb|Corbin|1993|p=48}} Accordingly, they have the power to commit sin but by their nature are able to avoid doing so, which is regarded as a miraculous gift from [[God in Islam|God]].{{harvnb|Nasr|Dabashi|Nasr|1989|p=98}} The Infallibles are believed to follow only God's desire in their actions because of their supreme righteousness, consciousness, and love for God.{{harvnb|Donaldson|1933|p=326}} They are also regarded as being immune to error in practical matters, in calling people to religion, and in the perception of divine knowledge.{{harvnb|Ansariyan|2007|p=89}} [[Shia]]s believe the Fourteen Infallibles are superior to the rest of creation and to the other major [[Prophets in Islam|prophets]].{{harvnb|Algar|1990}} == Family tree == [[File:Names of imameen.jpg|thumb|right|The fourteen infallibles.]] {{Familytree/start}} {{Familytree|boxstyle=background: | Baqir al-Ulum{{efn|The Revealer of Knowledge ({{lang-fa|باقرالعلوم}})}}{{Harvnb|Madelung|1988}} | {{bulleted list|677 – 732|57 – 114}}
Medina, [[Hijaz]], [[Arabian peninsula]] | Sunni and Shia sources consider Al-Baqir an early and pre-eminent [[Faqīh|legal scholar]] who was revered for having educated many students. | According to some Shia scholars, he was fatally poisoned by Ibrahim ibn Walid ibn 'Abdallah in Medina by order of Caliph [[Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik]].
Buried in Jannat al-Baqi, Medina |- | [[File:Jaffer-e-Sadiq.jpg|100px]] | [[Jafar al-Sadiq|Ja'far ibn Muhammad]]{{efn|جعفر بن محمد}}
Abu Abdillah{{efn|أبو عبدالله}}
| As-Sadiq{{efn|The Honest ({{lang-fa|صادق}})}}{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=15}} | {{bulleted list|702 – 765|83 – 148}}
Medina, [[Hijaz]], [[Arabian peninsula]] | As-Sadiq established the [[Ja'fari jurisprudence|Ja'fari school of jurisprudence]] and developed the [[Twelver#Theology|theology of the Twelvers]]. He taught many scholars in different fields, including [[Abu Hanifah]] and [[Malik ibn Anas]] in [[fiqh]], [[Wasil ibn Ata]] and [[Hisham ibn Hakam]] in [[Kalam|Islamic theology]], and [[Jābir ibn Hayyān|Geber]] in science and alchemy.{{harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=180}} | According to Shia sources, he was fatally poisoned in Medina by order of Caliph [[Al-Mansur]].
Buried in Jannat al-Baqi, Medina |- | [[File:Al-Kazim.jpg|100px]] | [[Musa al-Kazim|Musa ibn Ja'far]]{{efn|موسی بن جعفر}}
Abu al-Hasan I{{efn|أبو الحسن الاول}}{{Harvnb|Madelung|1985b}}
| Al-Kazim{{efn|The Calm One ({{lang-fa|کاظم}})}}{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=181}} | {{bulleted list|744 – 799|128 – 183}}
Medina, [[Hijaz]], [[Arabian peninsula]] | Al-Kazim was leader of the Shia community during the schism between the [[Ismaili]] and other branches of Islam after the death of the previous Imam Jafar al-Sadiq.{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=68}} He established a network of agents who collected the [[khums]] in the Shia community of the Middle East and the [[Greater Khorasan]]. He holds a high position in the [[Mahdavia]], the members of which trace their lineage to Muhammad through him.{{Harvnb|Sachedina|1988|pp=53–54}} | According to Shia belief, he was imprisoned and fatally poisoned in [[Baghdad]], Iraq, by order of Caliph [[Harun al-Rashid]].{{harvnb|Amir-Moezzi|2011|p=207}}
Buried in the [[Kazimayn|Kazimayn shrine]], Baghdad, Iraq |- | [[File:Al redah.jpg|100px]] | [[Ali al-Rida|Ali ibn Musa]]{{efn|علي بن موسی}}
Abu al-Hasan II{{efn|أبو الحسن الثانی}} | Ar-Rida{{efn|The Pleasing One ({{lang-fa|رضا}})}} | {{bulleted list|765 – 817|148 – 203}}
Medina,
[[Hijaz]], [[Arabian peninsula]]{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|pp=182–183}} | Made crown prince by Caliph [[Al-Ma'mun]], Ar-Rida was known for his discussions and debates with both Muslim and non-Muslim religious scholars.{{Harvnb|Chittick|1980|p=139}} | According to Shia sources, he was fatally poisoned in [[Mashad]], Iran, by order of Caliph Al-Ma'mun.
Buried in the [[Imam Reza shrine]], [[Mashad]], Iran |- | [[File:Imam Taqi.jpg|100px]] | [[Muhammad al-Taqi|Muhammad ibn Ali]]{{efn|محمد بن علي}}
Abu Ja'far{{efn|أبو جعفر}}
| Al-Taqi{{efn|The God-Fearing ({{lang-fa|تقی}})}} Al-Jawad{{efn|الجواد}}{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=183}} | {{bulleted list|809 or 810 – 835|195 – 220}}
Medina,
[[Hijaz]], [[Arabian peninsula]] | Al-Jawad was known for his generosity and piety in the face of persecution by the [[Abbasid|Abbasid caliphate]].{{harvnb|Qurashī|2005}} | According to Shia sources, he was fatally poisoned by his wife, the daughter of Caliph Al-Ma'mun, in Baghdad, Iraq, by order of Caliph [[Al-Mu'tasim]].
Buried in the [[Kazmain|Kazmain shrine]], Baghdad, Iraq. |- | [[File:Imam naqi.jpg|100px]] | [[Ali al-Hadi|Ali ibn Muhammad]]{{efn|علي بن محمد}}
Abu al-Hasan III{{efn|أبو الحسن الثالث}}{{Harvnb|Madelung|1985a}} | Al-Hadi{{efn|هادی}}{{harvnb|Dungersi|2005|p=16}} Al-Naqi{{efn|The Pure ({{lang-fa|نقی}})}} | {{bulleted list|828 – 868 |212 – 254}}
Surayya, a village near Medina, [[Hijaz]], [[Arabian peninsula]] | Al-Naqi taught religious sciences until 243/857. He strengthened the network of deputies in the Shia community. He sent them instructions and in turn received financial contributions from the faithful, from the [[khums]] and religious vows. | According to Shia sources, he was fatally poisoned in [[Samarra]], Iraq, by order of caliph [[Al-Mu'tazz]].
Buried in the [[Al Askari Mosque]], Samarra, Iraq. |- | [[File:Al-askari.svg|100px]] | [[Hasan al-Askari|Hasan ibn Ali]]{{efn|الحسن بن علي}}
Abu Muhammad{{efn|أبو محمد}} {{harvnb|Rizvi|1988|p=50}}
| Al-Askari{{efn|The Citizen of a Garrison Town ({{lang-fa|عسگری}})}}{{Harvnb|Halm|1987}} | {{bulleted list|845/6 – 874|231 – 260 }}
Medina,
[[Hijaz]], [[Arabian peninsula]] | Like his father, Al-Askari was placed under house arrest, which would last most of his life, by the Abbasid Caliph [[Al-Mu'tamid]], .{{Harvnb|Dungersi|2005|p=188}} During this time, repression of the Shia communities was great because of their growing size and power.{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=184}} | According to Shia belief, Al-Askari was fatally poisoned by order of Caliph Al-Mu'tamid in Samarra, Iraq.{{Harvnb|Dungersi|2005|p=196}}
Buried in the Al Askari Mosque, Samarra, Iraq. |- | [[File:Al mehdi.jpg|100px]] | [[Muhammad al-Mahdi|Muhammad ibn al-Hasan]]{{efn|محمد بن الحسن}}
Abu al-Qasim{{efn|أبو القاسم}}{{Harvnb|Amir-Moezzi|1994|p=174}}
| [[Mahdi]]{{efn| المهدی}}{{efn|The Guided One or The Guide ({{lang-fa|مهدی}})}}{{Harvnb|Amir-Moezzi|2007}} [[The Occultation|Hidden Imam]]{{efn| ({{lang-fa|امام غائب}})}}{{Harvnb|Amir-Moezzi|1994|p=115}} [[Hujjah|Al-Hujjah]]{{efn|The Proof ({{lang-fa|حجت}})}}''{{harvnb|Nasr|2013|p=161}} Sahib al-Zaman{{efn|The Lord of Our Times ({{lang-fa|صاحب الزمان}})}} Sahibu'l-Amr{{efn|The one vested with Divine authority ({{lang-fa|صاحب الامر}})}} Al-Qa'im{{efn|The Resurrector ({{lang-fa|قائم}})}} Baqiyyat Allah{{efn|God's Remainder ({{lang-fa|بقیةالله}})}} | {{bulleted list|868 – Unknown{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=186}}|255 or 256 – unknown}}
[[Samarra]], [[Iraq]]{{harvnb|Tabatabaei|1975|p=185}} | According to Twelver Shia doctrine, Baqiyyat Allah is a historical person, the current Imam, and the promised [[Mahdi]]—a messianic figure who will return with [[Jesus Christ]]. He will re-establish the rightful governance of Islam, filling the earth with justice and peace.{{Harvnb|Tabatabaei|1979|pp=211–214}} | According to Shia doctrine, Baqiyyat Allah has been living in the [[The Occultation|Occultation]] since 874 CE, and will continue living as long as God wills. |} == See also == {{portal|Shia Islam}} {{Twelvers|collapsed=2}} * [[Ahl al-Bayt]] * [[Ahl al-Kisa]] * [[Imamah (Shi'a twelver doctrine)]] * [[Ismah]] * [[Shia Islam]] * [[Twelve Imams]] * [[Twelvers]] ==Notes and references== ===Notes=== {{notes|30em}} ===References=== {{reflist|colwidth=25em|refs=}} ===Sources=== ; Encyclopedias * {{cite book|last = Ahmed|first = M.
